functions.desc: NetConn returns the underlying connection that is wrapped by c. Note that writing to or reading from this connection directly will corrupt the TLS session.

functions.name: OCSPResponse
functions.desc: OCSPResponse returns the stapled OCSP response from the TLS server, if any. (Only valid for client connections.)

functions.name: Read
functions.desc: Read reads data from the connection.  As Read calls [Conn.Handshake], in order to prevent indefinite blocking a deadline must be set for both Read and [Conn.Write] before Read is called when the handshake has not yet completed. See [Conn.SetDeadline], [Conn.SetReadDeadline], and [Conn.SetWriteDeadline].

functions.name: RemoteAddr
functions.desc: RemoteAddr returns the remote network address.

functions.name: SetDeadline
functions.desc: SetDeadline sets the read and write deadlines associated with the connection. A zero value for t means [Conn.Read] and [Conn.Write] will not time out. After a Write has timed out, the TLS state is corrupt and all future writes will return the same error.

functions.name: SetReadDeadline
functions.desc: SetReadDeadline sets the read deadline on the underlying connection. A zero value for t means [Conn.Read] will not time out.

functions.name: SetWriteDeadline
functions.desc: SetWriteDeadline sets the write deadline on the underlying connection. A zero value for t means [Conn.Write] will not time out. After a [Conn.Write] has timed out, the TLS state is corrupt and all future writes will return the same error.

functions.name: VerifyHostname
functions.desc: VerifyHostname checks that the peer certificate chain is valid for connecting to host. If so, it returns nil; if not, it returns an error describing the problem.

functions.name: Write
functions.desc: Write writes data to the connection.  As Write calls [Conn.Handshake], in order to prevent indefinite blocking a deadline must be set for both [Conn.Read] and Write before Write is called when the handshake has not yet completed. See [Conn.SetDeadline], [Conn.SetReadDeadline], and [Conn.SetWriteDeadline].

functions.name: clientSessionCacheKey
functions.desc: clientSessionCacheKey returns a key used to cache sessionTickets that could be used to resume previously negotiated TLS sessions with a server.

functions.name: handlePostHandshakeMessage
functions.desc: handlePostHandshakeMessage processes a handshake message arrived after the handshake is complete. Up to TLS 1.2, it indicates the start of a renegotiation.

functions.name: handleRenegotiation
functions.desc: handleRenegotiation processes a HelloRequest handshake message.

functions.name: maxPayloadSizeForWrite
functions.desc: maxPayloadSizeForWrite returns the maximum TLS payload size to use for the next application data record. There is the following trade-off:    - For latency-sensitive applications, such as web browsing, each TLS     record should fit in one TCP segment.   - For throughput-sensitive applications, such as large file transfers,     larger TLS records better amortize framing and encryption overheads.  A simple heuristic that works well in practice is to use small records for the first 1MB of data, then use larger records for subsequent data, and reset back to smaller records after the connection becomes idle. See "High Performance Web Networking", Chapter 4, or: https://www.igvita.com/2013/10/24/optimizing-tls-record-size-and-buffering-latency/  In the interests of simplicity and determinism, this code does not attempt to reset the record size once the connection is idle, however.

functions.name: processCertsFromClient
functions.desc: processCertsFromClient takes a chain of client certificates either from a certificateMsg message or a certificateMsgTLS13 message and verifies them.

functions.name: quicWaitForSignal
functions.desc: quicWaitForSignal notifies the QUICConn that handshake progress is blocked, and waits for a signal that the handshake should proceed.  The handshake may become blocked waiting for handshake bytes or for the user to provide transport parameters.

functions.name: readClientHello
functions.desc: readClientHello reads a ClientHello message and selects the protocol version.

functions.name: readFromUntil
functions.desc: readFromUntil reads from r into c.rawInput until c.rawInput contains at least n bytes or else returns an error.

functions.name: readHandshake
functions.desc: readHandshake reads the next handshake message from the record layer. If transcript is non-nil, the message is written to the passed transcriptHash.

functions.name: readHandshakeBytes
functions.desc: readHandshakeBytes reads handshake data until c.hand contains at least n bytes.

functions.name: readRecordOrCCS
functions.desc: readRecordOrCCS reads one or more TLS records from the connection and updates the record layer state. Some invariants:   - c.in must be locked   - c.input must be empty  During the handshake one and only one of the following will happen:   - c.hand grows   - c.in.changeCipherSpec is called   - an error is returned  After the handshake one and only one of the following will happen:   - c.hand grows   - c.input is set   - an error is returned

functions.name: retryReadRecord
functions.desc: retryReadRecord recurs into readRecordOrCCS to drop a non-advancing record, like a warning alert, empty application_data, or a change_cipher_spec in TLS 1.3.

functions.name: sendAlert
functions.desc: sendAlert sends a TLS alert message.

functions.name: sendAlertLocked
functions.desc: sendAlertLocked sends a TLS alert message.

functions.name: serverHandshake
functions.desc: serverHandshake performs a TLS handshake as a server.

functions.name: sessionState
functions.desc: sessionState returns a partially filled-out [SessionState] with information from the current connection.

functions.name: verifyServerCertificate
functions.desc: verifyServerCertificate parses and verifies the provided chain, setting c.verifiedChains and c.peerCertificates or sending the appropriate alert.

functions.name: writeChangeCipherRecord
functions.desc: writeChangeCipherRecord writes a ChangeCipherSpec message to the connection and updates the record layer state.

functions.name: writeHandshakeRecord
functions.desc: writeHandshakeRecord writes a handshake message to the connection and updates the record layer state. If transcript is non-nil the marshaled message is written to it.

functions.name: writeRecordLocked
functions.desc: writeRecordLocked writes a TLS record with the given type and payload to the connection and updates the record layer state.

functions.name: ExportKeyingMaterial
functions.desc: ExportKeyingMaterial returns length bytes of exported key material in a new slice as defined in RFC 5705. If context is nil, it is not used as part of the seed. If the connection was set to allow renegotiation via Config.Renegotiation, or if the connections supports neither TLS 1.3 nor Extended Master Secret, this function will return an error.  Exporting key material without Extended Master Secret or TLS 1.3 was disabled in Go 1.22 due to security issues (see the Security Considerations sections of RFC 5705 and RFC 7627), but can be re-enabled with the GODEBUG setting tlsunsafeekm=1.

functions.name: Dial
functions.desc: Dial connects to the given network address and initiates a TLS handshake, returning the resulting TLS connection.  The returned [Conn], if any, will always be of type *[Conn].  Dial uses context.Background internally; to specify the context, use [Dialer.DialContext].

functions.name: DialContext
functions.desc: DialContext connects to the given network address and initiates a TLS handshake, returning the resulting TLS connection.  The provided Context must be non-nil. If the context expires before the connection is complete, an error is returned. Once successfully connected, any expiration of the context will not affect the connection.  The returned [Conn], if any, will always be of type *[Conn].

functions.name: Close
functions.desc: Close closes the connection and stops any in-progress handshake.

functions.name: ConnectionState
functions.desc: ConnectionState returns basic TLS details about the connection.

functions.name: HandleData
functions.desc: HandleData handles handshake bytes received from the peer. It may produce connection events, which may be read with [QUICConn.NextEvent].

functions.name: NextEvent
functions.desc: NextEvent returns the next event occurring on the connection. It returns an event with a Kind of [QUICNoEvent] when no events are available.

functions.name: SendSessionTicket
functions.desc: SendSessionTicket sends a session ticket to the client. It produces connection events, which may be read with [QUICConn.NextEvent]. Currently, it can only be called once.

functions.name: SetTransportParameters
functions.desc: SetTransportParameters sets the transport parameters to send to the peer.  Server connections may delay setting the transport parameters until after receiving the client's transport parameters. See [QUICTransportParametersRequired].

functions.name: Start
functions.desc: Start starts the client or server handshake protocol. It may produce connection events, which may be read with [QUICConn.NextEvent].  Start must be called at most once.

functions.name: StoreSession
functions.desc: StoreSession stores a session previously received in a QUICStoreSession event in the ClientSessionCache. The application may process additional events or modify the SessionState before storing the session.

functions.name: Bytes
functions.desc: Bytes encodes the session, including any private fields, so that it can be parsed by [ParseSessionState]. The encoding contains secret values critical to the security of future and possibly past sessions.  The specific encoding should be considered opaque and may change incompatibly between Go versions.

functions.name: exportKeyingMaterial
functions.desc: exportKeyingMaterial implements RFC5705 exporters for TLS 1.3 according to RFC 8446, Section 7.5.

functions.name: finishedHash
functions.desc: finishedHash generates the Finished verify_data or PskBinderEntry according to RFC 8446, Section 4.4.4. See sections 4.4 and 4.2.11.2 for the baseKey selection.

functions.name: nextTrafficSecret
functions.desc: nextTrafficSecret generates the next traffic secret, given the current one, according to RFC 8446, Section 7.2.

functions.name: trafficKey
functions.desc: trafficKey generates traffic keys according to RFC 8446, Section 7.3.

functions.name: handshake
functions.desc: Does the handshake, either a full one or resumes old session. Requires hs.c, hs.hello, hs.serverHello, and, optionally, hs.session to be set.

functions.name: checkServerHelloOrHRR
functions.desc: checkServerHelloOrHRR does validity checks that apply to both ServerHello and HelloRetryRequest messages. It sets hs.suite.

functions.name: handshake
functions.desc: handshake requires hs.c, hs.hello, hs.serverHello, hs.keyShareKeys, and, optionally, hs.session, hs.earlySecret and hs.binderKey to be set.

functions.name: processHelloRetryRequest
functions.desc: processHelloRetryRequest handles the HRR in hs.serverHello, modifies and resends hs.hello, and reads the new ServerHello into hs.serverHello.

functions.name: sendDummyChangeCipherSpec
functions.desc: sendDummyChangeCipherSpec sends a ChangeCipherSpec record for compatibility with middleboxes that didn't implement TLS correctly. See RFC 8446, Appendix D.4.

functions.name: marshalWithoutBinders
functions.desc: marshalWithoutBinders returns the ClientHello through the PreSharedKeyExtension.identities field, according to RFC 8446, Section 4.2.11.2. Note that m.pskBinders must be set to slices of the correct length.

functions.name: updateBinders
functions.desc: updateBinders updates the m.pskBinders field. The supplied binders must have the same length as the current m.pskBinders.

functions.name: connFromCommand
functions.desc: connFromCommand starts the reference server process, connects to it and returns a recordingConn for the connection. The stdin return value is an opensslInput for the stdin of the child process. It must be closed before Waiting for child.

functions.name: clientSum
functions.desc: clientSum returns the contents of the verify_data member of a client's Finished message.

functions.name: discardHandshakeBuffer
functions.desc: discardHandshakeBuffer is called when there is no more need to buffer the entirety of the handshake messages.

functions.name: hashForClientCertificate
functions.desc: hashForClientCertificate returns the handshake messages so far, pre-hashed if necessary, suitable for signing by a TLS client certificate.

functions.name: serverSum
functions.desc: serverSum returns the contents of the verify_data member of a server's Finished message.

functions.name: changeCipherSpec
functions.desc: changeCipherSpec changes the encryption and MAC states to the ones previously passed to prepareCipherSpec.

functions.name: decrypt
functions.desc: decrypt authenticates and decrypts the record if protection is active at this stage. The returned plaintext might overlap with the input.

functions.name: encrypt
functions.desc: encrypt encrypts payload, adding the appropriate nonce and/or MAC, and appends it to record, which must already contain the record header.

functions.name: explicitNonceLen
functions.desc: explicitNonceLen returns the number of bytes of explicit nonce or IV included in each record. Explicit nonces are present only in CBC modes after TLS 1.0 and in certain AEAD modes in TLS 1.2.

functions.name: incSeq
functions.desc: incSeq increments the sequence number.

functions.name: prepareCipherSpec
functions.desc: prepareCipherSpec sets the encryption and MAC states that a subsequent changeCipherSpec will use.

functions.name: Accept
functions.desc: Accept waits for and returns the next incoming TLS connection. The returned connection is of type *Conn.

functions.name: Get
functions.desc: Get returns the [ClientSessionState] value associated with a given key. It returns (nil, false) if no value is found.

functions.name: Put
functions.desc: Put adds the provided (sessionKey, cs) pair to the cache. If cs is nil, the entry corresponding to sessionKey is removed from the cache instead.

functions.name: WriteTo
functions.desc: WriteTo writes Go source code to w that contains the recorded traffic.

functions.name: checkForResumption
functions.desc: checkForResumption reports whether we should perform resumption on this connection.

functions.name: sendDummyChangeCipherSpec
functions.desc: sendDummyChangeCipherSpec sends a ChangeCipherSpec record for compatibility with middleboxes that didn't implement TLS correctly. See RFC 8446, Appendix D.4.

functions.name: connFromCommand
functions.desc: connFromCommand starts opens a listening socket and starts the reference client to connect to it. It returns a recordingConn that wraps the resulting connection.

types.name: AlertError
types.desc: An AlertError is a TLS alert.  When using a QUIC transport, QUICConn methods will return an error which wraps AlertError rather than sending a TLS alert.

types.name: Certificate
types.desc: A Certificate is a chain of one or more certificates, leaf first.

types.name: CertificateRequestInfo
types.desc: CertificateRequestInfo contains information from a server's CertificateRequest message, which is used to demand a certificate and proof of control from a client.

types.name: CertificateVerificationError
types.desc: CertificateVerificationError is returned when certificate verification fails during the handshake.

types.name: CipherSuite
types.desc: CipherSuite is a TLS cipher suite. Note that most functions in this package accept and expose cipher suite IDs instead of this type.

types.name: ClientAuthType
types.desc: ClientAuthType declares the policy the server will follow for TLS Client Authentication.

types.name: ClientHelloInfo
types.desc: ClientHelloInfo contains information from a ClientHello message in order to guide application logic in the GetCertificate and GetConfigForClient callbacks.

types.name: ClientSessionCache
types.desc: ClientSessionCache is a cache of ClientSessionState objects that can be used by a client to resume a TLS session with a given server. ClientSessionCache implementations should expect to be called concurrently from different goroutines. Up to TLS 1.2, only ticket-based resumption is supported, not SessionID-based resumption. In TLS 1.3 they were merged into PSK modes, which are supported via this interface.

types.name: ClientSessionState
types.desc: ClientSessionState contains the state needed by a client to resume a previous TLS session.

types.name: Config
types.desc: A Config structure is used to configure a TLS client or server. After one has been passed to a TLS function it must not be modified. A Config may be reused; the tls package will also not modify it.

types.name: Conn
types.desc: A Conn represents a secured connection. It implements the net.Conn interface.

types.name: ConnectionState
types.desc: ConnectionState records basic TLS details about the connection.

types.name: CurveID
types.desc: CurveID is the type of a TLS identifier for a key exchange mechanism. See https://www.iana.org/assignments/tls-parameters/tls-parameters.xml#tls-parameters-8.  In TLS 1.2, this registry used to support only elliptic curves. In TLS 1.3, it was extended to other groups and renamed NamedGroup. See RFC 8446, Section 4.2.7. It was then also extended to other mechanisms, such as hybrid post-quantum KEMs.

types.name: Dialer
types.desc: Dialer dials TLS connections given a configuration and a Dialer for the underlying connection.

types.name: ECHRejectionError
types.desc: ECHRejectionError is the error type returned when ECH is rejected by a remote server. If the server offered a ECHConfigList to use for retries, the RetryConfigList field will contain this list.  The client may treat an ECHRejectionError with an empty set of RetryConfigs as a secure signal from the server.

types.name: EncryptedClientHelloKey
types.desc: EncryptedClientHelloKey holds a private key that is associated with a specific ECH config known to a client.

types.name: QUICConfig
types.desc: A QUICConfig configures a [QUICConn].

types.name: QUICConn
types.desc: A QUICConn represents a connection which uses a QUIC implementation as the underlying transport as described in RFC 9001.  Methods of QUICConn are not safe for concurrent use.

types.name: QUICEncryptionLevel
types.desc: QUICEncryptionLevel represents a QUIC encryption level used to transmit handshake messages.

types.name: QUICEvent
types.desc: A QUICEvent is an event occurring on a QUIC connection.  The type of event is specified by the Kind field. The contents of the other fields are kind-specific.

types.name: QUICEventKind
types.desc: A QUICEventKind is a type of operation on a QUIC connection.

types.name: RecordHeaderError
types.desc: RecordHeaderError is returned when a TLS record header is invalid.

types.name: RenegotiationSupport
types.desc: RenegotiationSupport enumerates the different levels of support for TLS renegotiation. TLS renegotiation is the act of performing subsequent handshakes on a connection after the first. This significantly complicates the state machine and has been the source of numerous, subtle security issues. Initiating a renegotiation is not supported, but support for accepting renegotiation requests may be enabled.  Even when enabled, the server may not change its identity between handshakes (i.e. the leaf certificate must be the same). Additionally, concurrent handshake and application data flow is not permitted so renegotiation can only be used with protocols that synchronise with the renegotiation, such as HTTPS.  Renegotiation is not defined in TLS 1.3.

types.name: SessionState
types.desc: A SessionState is a resumable session.

types.name: SignatureScheme
types.desc: SignatureScheme identifies a signature algorithm supported by TLS. See RFC 8446, Section 4.2.3.

types.name: atLeastReader
types.desc: atLeastReader reads from R, stopping with EOF once at least N bytes have been read. It is different from an io.LimitedReader in that it doesn't cut short the last Read call, and in that it considers an early EOF an error.

types.name: bogoResults
types.desc: bogoResults is a copy of boringssl.googlesource.com/boringssl/testresults.Results

types.name: brokenConn
types.desc: brokenConn wraps a net.Conn and causes all Writes after a certain number to fail with brokenConnErr.

types.name: cbcMode
types.desc: cbcMode is an interface for block ciphers using cipher block chaining.

types.name: changeImplConn
types.desc: changeImplConn is a net.Conn which can change its Write and Close methods.

types.name: cipherSuite
types.desc: A cipherSuite is a TLS 1.01.2 cipher suite, and defines the key exchange mechanism, as well as the cipher+MAC pair or the AEAD.

types.name: cipherSuiteTLS13
types.desc: A cipherSuiteTLS13 defines only the pair of the AEAD algorithm and hash algorithm to be used with HKDF. See RFC 8446, Appendix B.4.

types.name: clientTest
types.desc: clientTest represents a test of the TLS client handshake against a reference implementation.

types.name: cthWrapper
types.desc: cthWrapper wraps any hash.Hash that implements ConstantTimeSum, and replaces with that all calls to Sum. It's used to obtain a ConstantTimeSum-based HMAC.

types.name: discardConn
types.desc: discardConn wraps a net.Conn but discards all writes, but reports that they happened.

types.name: ecdheKeyAgreement
types.desc: ecdheKeyAgreement implements a TLS key agreement where the server generates an ephemeral EC public/private key pair and signs it. The pre-master secret is then calculated using ECDH. The signature may be ECDSA, Ed25519 or RSA.

types.name: finishedHash
types.desc: A finishedHash calculates the hash of a set of handshake messages suitable for including in a Finished message.

types.name: hairpinConn
types.desc: hairpinConn is a net.Conn that makes a hairpin call when closed, back into the tls.Conn which is calling it.

types.name: halfConn
types.desc: A halfConn represents one direction of the record layer connection, either sending or receiving.

types.name: keyAgreement
types.desc: A keyAgreement implements the client and server side of a TLS 1.01.2 key agreement protocol by generating and processing key exchange messages.

types.name: keyShare
types.desc: TLS 1.3 Key Share. See RFC 8446, Section 4.2.8.

types.name: listener
types.desc: A listener implements a network listener (net.Listener) for TLS connections.

types.name: lruSessionCache
types.desc: lruSessionCache is a ClientSessionCache implementation that uses an LRU caching strategy.

types.name: marshalingFunction
types.desc: The marshalingFunction type is an adapter to allow the use of ordinary functions as cryptobyte.MarshalingValue.

types.name: opensslInputEvent
types.desc: opensslInputEvent enumerates possible inputs that can be sent to an `openssl s_client` process.

types.name: opensslOutputSink
types.desc: opensslOutputSink is an io.Writer that receives the stdout and stderr from an `openssl` process and sends a value to handshakeComplete or readKeyUpdate when certain messages are seen.

types.name: prefixNonceAEAD
types.desc: prefixNonceAEAD wraps an AEAD and prefixes a fixed portion of the nonce to each call.

types.name: pskIdentity
types.desc: TLS 1.3 PSK Identity. Can be a Session Ticket, or a reference to a saved session. See RFC 8446, Section 4.2.11.

types.name: recordType
types.desc: TLS record types.

types.name: recordingConn
types.desc: recordingConn is a net.Conn that records the traffic that passes through it. WriteTo can be used to produce output that can be later be loaded with ParseTestData.

types.name: replayingConn
types.desc: replayingConn is a net.Conn that replays flows recorded by recordingConn.

types.name: rsaKeyAgreement
types.desc: rsaKeyAgreement implements the standard TLS key agreement where the client encrypts the pre-master secret to the server's public key.

types.name: serverHandshakeState
types.desc: serverHandshakeState contains details of a server handshake in progress. It's discarded once the handshake has completed.

types.name: serverTest
types.desc: serverTest represents a test of the TLS server handshake against a reference implementation.

types.name: ticketKey
types.desc: ticketKey is the internal representation of a session ticket key.

types.name: weakCertCache
types.desc: weakCertCache provides a cache of *x509.Certificates, allowing multiple connections to reuse parsed certificates, instead of re-parsing the certificate for every connection, which is an expensive operation.

types.name: writeCountingConn
types.desc: writeCountingConn wraps a net.Conn and counts the number of Write calls.

types.name: xorNonceAEAD
types.desc: xorNonceAEAD wraps an AEAD by XORing in a fixed pattern to the nonce before each call.

types.name: zeroSource
types.desc: zeroSource is an io.Reader that returns an unlimited number of zero bytes.

name: crypto/tls/fipsonly
desc: Package fipsonly restricts all TLS configuration to FIPS-approved settings.  The effect is triggered by importing the package anywhere in a program, as in:  	import _ "crypto/tls/fipsonly"  This package only exists when using Go compiled with GOEXPERIMENT=boringcrypto.

name: crypto/x509
desc: Package x509 implements a subset of the X.509 standard.  It allows parsing and generating certificates, certificate signing requests, certificate revocation lists, and encoded public and private keys. It provides a certificate verifier, complete with a chain builder.  The package targets the X.509 technical profile defined by the IETF (RFC 2459/3280/5280), and as further restricted by the CA/Browser Forum Baseline Requirements. There is minimal support for features outside of these profiles, as the primary goal of the package is to provide compatibility with the publicly trusted TLS certificate ecosystem and its policies and constraints.  On macOS and Windows, certificate verification is handled by system APIs, but the package aims to apply consistent validation rules across operating systems.

functions.name: CreateCertificate
functions.desc: CreateCertificate creates a new X.509 v3 certificate based on a template. The following members of template are currently used:    - AuthorityKeyId   - BasicConstraintsValid   - CRLDistributionPoints   - DNSNames   - EmailAddresses   - ExcludedDNSDomains   - ExcludedEmailAddresses   - ExcludedIPRanges   - ExcludedURIDomains   - ExtKeyUsage   - ExtraExtensions   - IPAddresses   - IsCA   - IssuingCertificateURL   - KeyUsage   - MaxPathLen   - MaxPathLenZero   - NotAfter   - NotBefore   - OCSPServer   - PermittedDNSDomains   - PermittedDNSDomainsCritical   - PermittedEmailAddresses   - PermittedIPRanges   - PermittedURIDomains   - PolicyIdentifiers (see note below)   - Policies (see note below)   - SerialNumber   - SignatureAlgorithm   - Subject   - SubjectKeyId   - URIs   - UnknownExtKeyUsage  The certificate is signed by parent. If parent is equal to template then the certificate is self-signed. The parameter pub is the public key of the certificate to be generated and priv is the private key of the signer.  The returned slice is the certificate in DER encoding.  The currently supported key types are *rsa.PublicKey, *ecdsa.PublicKey and ed25519.PublicKey. pub must be a supported key type, and priv must be a crypto.Signer or crypto.MessageSigner with a supported public key.  The AuthorityKeyId will be taken from the SubjectKeyId of parent, if any, unless the resulting certificate is self-signed. Otherwise the value from template will be used.  If SubjectKeyId from template is empty and the template is a CA, SubjectKeyId will be generated from the hash of the public key.  If template.SerialNumber is nil, a serial number will be generated which conforms to RFC 5280, Section 4.1.2.2 using entropy from rand.  The PolicyIdentifier and Policies fields can both be used to marshal certificate policy OIDs. By default, only the Policies is marshaled, but if the GODEBUG setting "x509usepolicies" has the value "0", the PolicyIdentifiers field will be marshaled instead of the Policies field. This changed in Go 1.24. The Policies field can be used to marshal policy OIDs which have components that are larger than 31 bits.

functions.name: CreateCertificateRequest
functions.desc: CreateCertificateRequest creates a new certificate request based on a template. The following members of template are used:    - SignatureAlgorithm   - Subject   - DNSNames   - EmailAddresses   - IPAddresses   - URIs   - ExtraExtensions   - Attributes (deprecated)  priv is the private key to sign the CSR with, and the corresponding public key will be included in the CSR. It must implement crypto.Signer or crypto.MessageSigner and its Public() method must return a *rsa.PublicKey or a *ecdsa.PublicKey or a ed25519.PublicKey. (A *rsa.PrivateKey, *ecdsa.PrivateKey or ed25519.PrivateKey satisfies this.)  The returned slice is the certificate request in DER encoding.

functions.name: CreateRevocationList
functions.desc: CreateRevocationList creates a new X.509 v2 [Certificate] Revocation List, according to RFC 5280, based on template.  The CRL is signed by priv which should be a crypto.Signer or crypto.MessageSigner associated with the public key in the issuer certificate.  The issuer may not be nil, and the crlSign bit must be set in [KeyUsage] in order to use it as a CRL issuer.  The issuer distinguished name CRL field and authority key identifier extension are populated using the issuer certificate. issuer must have SubjectKeyId set.

functions.name: DecryptPEMBlock
functions.desc: DecryptPEMBlock takes a PEM block encrypted according to RFC 1423 and the password used to encrypt it and returns a slice of decrypted DER encoded bytes. It inspects the DEK-Info header to determine the algorithm used for decryption. If no DEK-Info header is present, an error is returned. If an incorrect password is detected an [IncorrectPasswordError] is returned. Because of deficiencies in the format, it's not always possible to detect an incorrect password. In these cases no error will be returned but the decrypted DER bytes will be random noise.  Deprecated: Legacy PEM encryption as specified in RFC 1423 is insecure by design. Since it does not authenticate the ciphertext, it is vulnerable to padding oracle attacks that can let an attacker recover the plaintext.

functions.name: EncryptPEMBlock
functions.desc: EncryptPEMBlock returns a PEM block of the specified type holding the given DER encoded data encrypted with the specified algorithm and password according to RFC 1423.  Deprecated: Legacy PEM encryption as specified in RFC 1423 is insecure by design. Since it does not authenticate the ciphertext, it is vulnerable to padding oracle attacks that can let an attacker recover the plaintext.

functions.name: IsEncryptedPEMBlock
functions.desc: IsEncryptedPEMBlock returns whether the PEM block is password encrypted according to RFC 1423.  Deprecated: Legacy PEM encryption as specified in RFC 1423 is insecure by design. Since it does not authenticate the ciphertext, it is vulnerable to padding oracle attacks that can let an attacker recover the plaintext.

functions.name: MarshalECPrivateKey
functions.desc: MarshalECPrivateKey converts an EC private key to SEC 1, ASN.1 DER form.  This kind of key is commonly encoded in PEM blocks of type "EC PRIVATE KEY". For a more flexible key format which is not EC specific, use [MarshalPKCS8PrivateKey].

functions.name: MarshalPKCS1PrivateKey
functions.desc: MarshalPKCS1PrivateKey converts an [RSA] private key to PKCS #1, ASN.1 DER form.  This kind of key is commonly encoded in PEM blocks of type "RSA PRIVATE KEY". For a more flexible key format which is not [RSA] specific, use [MarshalPKCS8PrivateKey].  The key must have passed validation by calling [rsa.PrivateKey.Validate] first. MarshalPKCS1PrivateKey calls [rsa.PrivateKey.Precompute], which may modify the key if not already precomputed.

functions.name: MarshalPKCS1PublicKey
functions.desc: MarshalPKCS1PublicKey converts an [RSA] public key to PKCS #1, ASN.1 DER form.  This kind of key is commonly encoded in PEM blocks of type "RSA PUBLIC KEY".

functions.name: MarshalPKCS8PrivateKey
functions.desc: MarshalPKCS8PrivateKey converts a private key to PKCS #8, ASN.1 DER form.  The following key types are currently supported: *[rsa.PrivateKey], *[ecdsa.PrivateKey], [ed25519.PrivateKey] (not a pointer), and *[ecdh.PrivateKey]. Unsupported key types result in an error.  This kind of key is commonly encoded in PEM blocks of type "PRIVATE KEY".  MarshalPKCS8PrivateKey runs [rsa.PrivateKey.Precompute] on RSA keys.

functions.name: MarshalPKIXPublicKey
functions.desc: MarshalPKIXPublicKey converts a public key to PKIX, ASN.1 DER form. The encoded public key is a SubjectPublicKeyInfo structure (see RFC 5280, Section 4.1).  The following key types are currently supported: *[rsa.PublicKey], *[ecdsa.PublicKey], [ed25519.PublicKey] (not a pointer), and *[ecdh.PublicKey]. Unsupported key types result in an error.  This kind of key is commonly encoded in PEM blocks of type "PUBLIC KEY".

functions.name: ParseCRL
functions.desc: ParseCRL parses a CRL from the given bytes. It's often the case that PEM encoded CRLs will appear where they should be DER encoded, so this function will transparently handle PEM encoding as long as there isn't any leading garbage.  Deprecated: Use [ParseRevocationList] instead.

functions.name: ParseDERCRL
functions.desc: ParseDERCRL parses a DER encoded CRL from the given bytes.  Deprecated: Use [ParseRevocationList] instead.

functions.name: ParseECPrivateKey
functions.desc: ParseECPrivateKey parses an EC private key in SEC 1, ASN.1 DER form.  This kind of key is commonly encoded in PEM blocks of type "EC PRIVATE KEY".

functions.name: ParsePKCS1PrivateKey
functions.desc: ParsePKCS1PrivateKey parses an [RSA] private key in PKCS #1, ASN.1 DER form.  This kind of key is commonly encoded in PEM blocks of type "RSA PRIVATE KEY".  Before Go 1.24, the CRT parameters were ignored and recomputed. To restore the old behavior, use the GODEBUG=x509rsacrt=0 environment variable.

functions.name: ParsePKCS1PublicKey
functions.desc: ParsePKCS1PublicKey parses an [RSA] public key in PKCS #1, ASN.1 DER form.  This kind of key is commonly encoded in PEM blocks of type "RSA PUBLIC KEY".

functions.name: ParsePKCS8PrivateKey
functions.desc: ParsePKCS8PrivateKey parses an unencrypted private key in PKCS #8, ASN.1 DER form.  It returns a *[rsa.PrivateKey], an *[ecdsa.PrivateKey], an [ed25519.PrivateKey] (not a pointer), or an *[ecdh.PrivateKey] (for X25519). More types might be supported in the future.  This kind of key is commonly encoded in PEM blocks of type "PRIVATE KEY".  Before Go 1.24, the CRT parameters of RSA keys were ignored and recomputed. To restore the old behavior, use the GODEBUG=x509rsacrt=0 environment variable.

functions.name: ParsePKIXPublicKey
functions.desc: ParsePKIXPublicKey parses a public key in PKIX, ASN.1 DER form. The encoded public key is a SubjectPublicKeyInfo structure (see RFC 5280, Section 4.1).  It returns a *[rsa.PublicKey], *[dsa.PublicKey], *[ecdsa.PublicKey], [ed25519.PublicKey] (not a pointer), or *[ecdh.PublicKey] (for X25519). More types might be supported in the future.  This kind of key is commonly encoded in PEM blocks of type "PUBLIC KEY".

functions.name: SetFallbackRoots
functions.desc: SetFallbackRoots sets the roots to use during certificate verification, if no custom roots are specified and a platform verifier or a system certificate pool is not available (for instance in a container which does not have a root certificate bundle). SetFallbackRoots will panic if roots is nil.  SetFallbackRoots may only be called once, if called multiple times it will panic.  The fallback behavior can be forced on all platforms, even when there is a system certificate pool, by setting GODEBUG=x509usefallbackroots=1 (note that on Windows and macOS this will disable usage of the platform verification APIs and cause the pure Go verifier to be used). Setting x509usefallbackroots=1 without calling SetFallbackRoots has no effect.

functions.name: TestLoadSystemCertsLoadColonSeparatedDirs
functions.desc: Ensure that "SSL_CERT_DIR" when used as the environment variable delimited by colons, allows loadSystemRoots to load all the roots from the respective directories. See https://golang.org/issue/35325.

functions.name: alreadyInChain
functions.desc: alreadyInChain checks whether a candidate certificate is present in a chain. Rather than doing a direct byte for byte equivalency check, we check if the subject, public key, and SAN, if present, are equal. This prevents loops that are created by mutual cross-signatures, or other cross-signature bridge oddities.

functions.name: asn1BitLength
functions.desc: asn1BitLength returns the bit-length of bitString by considering the most-significant bit in a byte to be the "first" bit. This convention matches ASN.1, but differs from almost everything else.

functions.name: certPoolEqual
functions.desc: certPoolEqual reports whether a and b are equal, except for the function pointers.

functions.name: checkChainSSLServerPolicy
functions.desc: checkChainSSLServerPolicy checks that the certificate chain in chainCtx is valid for use as a certificate chain for a SSL/TLS server.

functions.name: checkChainTrustStatus
functions.desc: checkChainTrustStatus checks the trust status of the certificate chain, translating any errors it finds into Go errors in the process.

functions.name: checkSignature
functions.desc: checkSignature verifies that signature is a valid signature over signed from a crypto.PublicKey.

functions.name: createStoreContext
functions.desc: Creates a new *syscall.CertContext representing the leaf certificate in an in-memory certificate store containing itself and all of the intermediate certificates specified in the opts.Intermediates CertPool.  A pointer to the in-memory store is available in the returned CertContext's Store field. The store is automatically freed when the CertContext is freed using syscall.CertFreeCertificateContext.

functions.name: domainNameValid
functions.desc: domainNameValid is an alloc-less version of the checks that domainToReverseLabels does.

functions.name: domainToReverseLabels
functions.desc: domainToReverseLabels converts a textual domain name like foo.example.com to the list of labels in reverse order, e.g. ["com", "example", "foo"].

functions.name: dsaSelfSignedCNX
functions.desc: dsaSelfSignedCNX produces DER-encoded certificate with the properties:  	Subject=Issuer=CN=X 	DSA SPKI 	Matching inner/outer signature OIDs 	Dummy ECDSA signature

functions.name: isPrintable
functions.desc: isPrintable reports whether the given b is in the ASN.1 PrintableString set. This is a simplified version of encoding/asn1.isPrintable.

functions.name: isSameDirSymlink
functions.desc: isSameDirSymlink reports whether fi in dir is a symlink with a target not containing a slash.

functions.name: isValidIPMask
functions.desc: isValidIPMask reports whether mask consists of zero or more 1 bits, followed by zero bits.

functions.name: marshalECDHPrivateKey
functions.desc: marshalECDHPrivateKey marshals an EC private key into ASN.1, DER format suitable for NIST curves.

functions.name: marshalECPrivateKeyWithOID
functions.desc: marshalECPrivateKeyWithOID marshals an EC private key into ASN.1, DER format and sets the curve ID to the given OID, or omits it if OID is nil.

functions.name: marshalSANs
functions.desc: marshalSANs marshals a list of addresses into a the contents of an X.509 SubjectAlternativeName extension.

functions.name: newRawAttributes
functions.desc: newRawAttributes converts AttributeTypeAndValueSETs from a template CertificateRequest's Attributes into tbsCertificateRequest RawAttributes.

functions.name: oidInExtensions
functions.desc: oidInExtensions reports whether an extension with the given oid exists in extensions.

functions.name: parseASN1String
functions.desc: parseASN1String parses the ASN.1 string types T61String, PrintableString, UTF8String, BMPString, IA5String, and NumericString. This is mostly copied from the respective encoding/asn1.parse... methods, rather than just increasing the API surface of that package.

functions.name: parseCSRExtensions
functions.desc: parseCSRExtensions parses the attributes from a CSR and extracts any requested extensions.

functions.name: parseECPrivateKey
functions.desc: parseECPrivateKey parses an ASN.1 Elliptic Curve Private Key Structure. The OID for the named curve may be provided from another source (such as the PKCS8 container) - if it is provided then use this instead of the OID that may exist in the EC private key structure.

functions.name: parseName
functions.desc: parseName parses a DER encoded Name as defined in RFC 5280. We may want to export this function in the future for use in crypto/tls.

functions.name: parseRawAttributes
functions.desc: parseRawAttributes Unmarshals RawAttributes into AttributeTypeAndValueSETs.

functions.name: readUniqueDirectoryEntries
functions.desc: readUniqueDirectoryEntries is like os.ReadDir but omits symlinks that point within the directory.

functions.name: toLowerCaseASCII
functions.desc: toLowerCaseASCII returns a lower-case version of in. See RFC 6125 6.4.1. We use an explicitly ASCII function to avoid any sharp corners resulting from performing Unicode operations on DNS labels.

functions.name: validHostname
functions.desc: validHostname reports whether host is a valid hostname that can be matched or matched against according to RFC 6125 2.2, with some leniency to accommodate legacy values.

functions.name: AddCert
functions.desc: AddCert adds a certificate to a pool.

functions.name: AddCertWithConstraint
functions.desc: AddCertWithConstraint adds a certificate to the pool with the additional constraint. When Certificate.Verify builds a chain which is rooted by cert, it will additionally pass the whole chain to constraint to determine its validity. If constraint returns a non-nil error, the chain will be discarded. constraint may be called concurrently from multiple goroutines.

functions.name: AppendCertsFromPEM
functions.desc: AppendCertsFromPEM attempts to parse a series of PEM encoded certificates. It appends any certificates found to s and reports whether any certificates were successfully parsed.  On many Linux systems, /etc/ssl/cert.pem will contain the system wide set of root CAs in a format suitable for this function.

functions.name: Clone
functions.desc: Clone returns a copy of s.

functions.name: Equal
functions.desc: Equal reports whether s and other are equal.

functions.name: Subjects
functions.desc: Subjects returns a list of the DER-encoded subjects of all of the certificates in the pool.  Deprecated: if s was returned by [SystemCertPool], Subjects will not include the system roots.

functions.name: addCertFunc
functions.desc: addCertFunc adds metadata about a certificate to a pool, along with a func to fetch that certificate later when needed.  The rawSubject is Certificate.RawSubject and must be non-empty. The getCert func may be called 0 or more times.

functions.name: cert
functions.desc: cert returns cert index n in s.

functions.name: findPotentialParents
functions.desc: findPotentialParents returns the certificates in s which might have signed cert.

functions.name: len
functions.desc: len returns the number of certs in the set. A nil set is a valid empty set.

functions.name: CheckCRLSignature
functions.desc: CheckCRLSignature checks that the signature in crl is from c.  Deprecated: Use [RevocationList.CheckSignatureFrom] instead.

functions.name: CheckSignature
functions.desc: CheckSignature verifies that signature is a valid signature over signed from c's public key.  This is a low-level API that performs no validity checks on the certificate.  [MD5WithRSA] signatures are rejected, while [SHA1WithRSA] and [ECDSAWithSHA1] signatures are currently accepted.

functions.name: CheckSignatureFrom
functions.desc: CheckSignatureFrom verifies that the signature on c is a valid signature from parent.  This is a low-level API that performs very limited checks, and not a full path verifier. Most users should use [Certificate.Verify] instead.

functions.name: CreateCRL
functions.desc: CreateCRL returns a DER encoded CRL, signed by this Certificate, that contains the given list of revoked certificates.  Deprecated: this method does not generate an RFC 5280 conformant X.509 v2 CRL. To generate a standards compliant CRL, use [CreateRevocationList] instead.

functions.name: Verify
functions.desc: Verify attempts to verify c by building one or more chains from c to a certificate in opts.Roots, using certificates in opts.Intermediates if needed. If successful, it returns one or more chains where the first element of the chain is c and the last element is from opts.Roots.  If opts.Roots is nil, the platform verifier might be used, and verification details might differ from what is described below. If system roots are unavailable the returned error will be of type SystemRootsError.  Name constraints in the intermediates will be applied to all names claimed in the chain, not just opts.DNSName. Thus it is invalid for a leaf to claim example.com if an intermediate doesn't permit it, even if example.com is not the name being validated. Note that DirectoryName constraints are not supported.  Name constraint validation follows the rules from RFC 5280, with the addition that DNS name constraints may use the leading period format defined for emails and URIs. When a constraint has a leading period it indicates that at least one additional label must be prepended to the constrained name to be considered valid.  Extended Key Usage values are enforced nested down a chain, so an intermediate or root that enumerates EKUs prevents a leaf from asserting an EKU not in that list. (While this is not specified, it is common practice in order to limit the types of certificates a CA can issue.)  Certificates that use SHA1WithRSA and ECDSAWithSHA1 signatures are not supported, and will not be used to build chains.  Certificates other than c in the returned chains should not be modified.  WARNING: this function doesn't do any revocation checking.

functions.name: VerifyHostname
functions.desc: VerifyHostname returns nil if c is a valid certificate for the named host. Otherwise it returns an error describing the mismatch.  IP addresses can be optionally enclosed in square brackets and are checked against the IPAddresses field. Other names are checked case insensitively against the DNSNames field. If the names are valid hostnames, the certificate fields can have a wildcard as the complete left-most label (e.g. *.example.com).  Note that the legacy Common Name field is ignored.

functions.name: checkNameConstraints
functions.desc: checkNameConstraints checks that c permits a child certificate to claim the given name, of type nameType. The argument parsedName contains the parsed form of name, suitable for passing to the match function. The total number of comparisons is tracked in the given count and should not exceed the given limit.

functions.name: isValid
functions.desc: isValid performs validity checks on c given that it is a candidate to append to the chain in currentChain.

functions.name: systemVerify
functions.desc: systemVerify is like Verify, except that it uses CryptoAPI calls to build certificate chains and verify them.

functions.name: CheckSignature
functions.desc: CheckSignature reports whether the signature on c is valid.

functions.name: AppendBinary
functions.desc: AppendBinary implements [encoding.BinaryAppender]

functions.name: AppendText
functions.desc: AppendText implements [encoding.TextAppender]

functions.name: Equal
functions.desc: Equal returns true when oid and other represents the same Object Identifier.

functions.name: EqualASN1OID
functions.desc: EqualASN1OID returns whether an OID equals an asn1.ObjectIdentifier. If asn1.ObjectIdentifier cannot represent the OID specified by oid, because a component of OID requires more than 31 bits, it returns false.

functions.name: MarshalBinary
functions.desc: MarshalBinary implements [encoding.BinaryMarshaler]

functions.name: MarshalText
functions.desc: MarshalText implements [encoding.TextMarshaler]

functions.name: String
functions.desc: Strings returns the string representation of the Object Identifier.

functions.name: UnmarshalBinary
functions.desc: UnmarshalBinary implements [encoding.BinaryUnmarshaler]

functions.name: UnmarshalText
functions.desc: UnmarshalText implements [encoding.TextUnmarshaler]

functions.name: CheckSignatureFrom
functions.desc: CheckSignatureFrom verifies that the signature on rl is a valid signature from issuer.

functions.name: deriveKey
functions.desc: deriveKey uses a key derivation function to stretch the password into a key with the number of bits our cipher requires. This algorithm was derived from the OpenSSL source.

types.name: CertPool
types.desc: CertPool is a set of certificates.

types.name: Certificate
types.desc: A Certificate represents an X.509 certificate.

types.name: CertificateInvalidError
types.desc: CertificateInvalidError results when an odd error occurs. Users of this library probably want to handle all these errors uniformly.

types.name: CertificateRequest
types.desc: CertificateRequest represents a PKCS #10, certificate signature request.

types.name: ConstraintViolationError
types.desc: ConstraintViolationError results when a requested usage is not permitted by a certificate. For example: checking a signature when the public key isn't a certificate signing key.

types.name: ExtKeyUsage
types.desc: ExtKeyUsage represents an extended set of actions that are valid for a given key. Each of the ExtKeyUsage* constants define a unique action.

types.name: HostnameError
types.desc: HostnameError results when the set of authorized names doesn't match the requested name.

types.name: InsecureAlgorithmError
types.desc: An InsecureAlgorithmError indicates that the [SignatureAlgorithm] used to generate the signature is not secure, and the signature has been rejected.

types.name: KeyUsage
types.desc: KeyUsage represents the set of actions that are valid for a given key. It's a bitmap of the KeyUsage* constants.

types.name: OID
types.desc: An OID represents an ASN.1 OBJECT IDENTIFIER.

types.name: PolicyMapping
types.desc: PolicyMapping represents a policy mapping entry in the policyMappings extension.

types.name: RevocationList
types.desc: RevocationList represents a [Certificate] Revocation List (CRL) as specified by RFC 5280.

types.name: RevocationListEntry
types.desc: RevocationListEntry represents an entry in the revokedCertificates sequence of a CRL.

types.name: SystemRootsError
types.desc: SystemRootsError results when we fail to load the system root certificates.

types.name: UnknownAuthorityError
types.desc: UnknownAuthorityError results when the certificate issuer is unknown

types.name: VerifyOptions
types.desc: VerifyOptions contains parameters for Certificate.Verify.

types.name: certificateList
types.desc: These structures reflect the ASN.1 structure of X.509 CRLs better than the existing crypto/x509/pkix variants do. These mirror the existing certificate structs in this file.  Notably, we include issuer as an asn1.RawValue, mirroring the behavior of tbsCertificate and allowing raw (unparsed) subjects to be passed cleanly.

types.name: ecPrivateKey
types.desc: ecPrivateKey reflects an ASN.1 Elliptic Curve Private Key Structure. References:  	RFC 5915 	SEC1 - http://www.secg.org/sec1-v2.pdf  Per RFC 5915 the NamedCurveOID is marked as ASN.1 OPTIONAL, however in most cases it is not.

types.name: lazyCert
types.desc: lazyCert is minimal metadata about a Cert and a func to retrieve it in its normal expanded *Certificate form.

types.name: pkcs1PrivateKey
types.desc: pkcs1PrivateKey is a structure which mirrors the PKCS #1 ASN.1 for an RSA private key.

types.name: pkcs1PublicKey
types.desc: pkcs1PublicKey reflects the ASN.1 structure of a PKCS #1 public key.

types.name: pkcs8
types.desc: pkcs8 reflects an ASN.1, PKCS #8 PrivateKey. See ftp://ftp.rsasecurity.com/pub/pkcs/pkcs-8/pkcs-8v1_2.asn and RFC 5208.

types.name: pkixPublicKey
types.desc: pkixPublicKey reflects a PKIX public key structure. See SubjectPublicKeyInfo in RFC 3280.

types.name: pssParameters
types.desc: pssParameters reflects the parameters in an AlgorithmIdentifier that specifies RSA PSS. See RFC 3447, Appendix A.2.3.

types.name: rfc1423Algo
types.desc: rfc1423Algo holds a method for enciphering a PEM block.

types.name: rfc2821Mailbox
types.desc: rfc2821Mailbox represents a mailbox (which is an email address to most people) by breaking it into the local (i.e. before the '@') and domain parts.

name: crypto/x509/pkix
desc: Package pkix contains shared, low level structures used for ASN.1 parsing and serialization of X.509 certificates, CRL and OCSP.

functions.name: oidInAttributeTypeAndValue
functions.desc: oidInAttributeTypeAndValue reports whether a type with the given OID exists in atv.

functions.name: HasExpired
functions.desc: HasExpired reports whether certList should have been updated by now.

functions.name: FillFromRDNSequence
functions.desc: FillFromRDNSequence populates n from the provided [RDNSequence]. Multi-entry RDNs are flattened, all entries are added to the relevant n fields, and the grouping is not preserved.

functions.name: String
functions.desc: String returns the string form of n, roughly following the RFC 2253 Distinguished Names syntax.

functions.name: ToRDNSequence
functions.desc: ToRDNSequence converts n into a single [RDNSequence]. The following attributes are encoded as multi-value RDNs:    - Country   - Organization   - OrganizationalUnit   - Locality   - Province   - StreetAddress   - PostalCode  Each ExtraNames entry is encoded as an individual RDN.

functions.name: appendRDNs
functions.desc: appendRDNs appends a relativeDistinguishedNameSET to the given RDNSequence and returns the new value. The relativeDistinguishedNameSET contains an attributeTypeAndValue for each of the given values. See RFC 5280, A.1, and search for AttributeTypeAndValue.

functions.name: String
functions.desc: String returns a string representation of the sequence r, roughly following the RFC 2253 Distinguished Names syntax.

types.name: AlgorithmIdentifier
types.desc: AlgorithmIdentifier represents the ASN.1 structure of the same name. See RFC 5280, section 4.1.1.2.

types.name: AttributeTypeAndValue
types.desc: AttributeTypeAndValue mirrors the ASN.1 structure of the same name in RFC 5280, Section 4.1.2.4.

types.name: AttributeTypeAndValueSET
types.desc: AttributeTypeAndValueSET represents a set of ASN.1 sequences of [AttributeTypeAndValue] sequences from RFC 2986 (PKCS #10).

types.name: CertificateList
types.desc: CertificateList represents the ASN.1 structure of the same name. See RFC 5280, section 5.1. Use Certificate.CheckCRLSignature to verify the signature.  Deprecated: x509.RevocationList should be used instead.

types.name: Extension
types.desc: Extension represents the ASN.1 structure of the same name. See RFC 5280, section 4.2.

types.name: Name
types.desc: Name represents an X.509 distinguished name. This only includes the common elements of a DN. Note that Name is only an approximation of the X.509 structure. If an accurate representation is needed, asn1.Unmarshal the raw subject or issuer as an [RDNSequence].

types.name: RevokedCertificate
types.desc: RevokedCertificate represents the ASN.1 structure of the same name. See RFC 5280, section 5.1.

types.name: TBSCertificateList
types.desc: TBSCertificateList represents the ASN.1 structure of the same name. See RFC 5280, section 5.1.  Deprecated: x509.RevocationList should be used instead.

name: database/sql
desc: Package sql provides a generic interface around SQL (or SQL-like) databases.  The sql package must be used in conjunction with a database driver. See https://golang.org/s/sqldrivers for a list of drivers.  Drivers that do not support context cancellation will not return until after the query is completed.  For usage examples, see the wiki page at https://golang.org/s/sqlwiki.

functions.name: Drivers
functions.desc: Drivers returns a sorted list of the names of the registered drivers.

functions.name: Register
functions.desc: Register makes a database driver available by the provided name. If Register is called twice with the same name or if driver is nil, it panics.

functions.name: TestBadDriver
functions.desc: Issue 15901.

functions.name: TestBogusPreboundParameters
functions.desc: just a test of fakedb itself

functions.name: TestCloseConnBeforeStmts
functions.desc: golang.org/issue/5046

functions.name: TestCloseStmtBeforeRows
functions.desc: From golang.org/issue/3865

functions.name: TestConnExpiresFreshOutOfPool
functions.desc: Issue32530 encounters an issue where a connection may expire right after it comes out of a used connection pool even when a new connection is requested.

functions.name: TestConnIsValid
functions.desc: TestConnIsValid verifies that a database connection that should be discarded, is actually discarded and does not re-enter the connection pool. If the IsValid method from *fakeConn is removed, this test will fail.

functions.name: TestDriverArgsWrapsErrors
functions.desc: Issue 64707: Ensure that Stmt.Exec and Stmt.Query properly wraps underlying errors.

functions.name: TestErrBadConnReconnect
functions.desc: golang.org/issue/5718

functions.name: TestIssue18429
functions.desc: TestIssue18429 attempts to stress rolling back the transaction from a context cancel while simultaneously calling Tx.Rollback. Rolling back from a context happens concurrently so tx.rollback and tx.Commit must guard against double entry.  In the test, a context is canceled while the query is in process so the internal rollback will run concurrently with the explicitly called Tx.Rollback.  The addition of calling rows.Next also tests Issue 21117.

functions.name: TestIssue18719
functions.desc: TestIssue18719 closes the context right before use. The sql.driverConn will nil out the ci on close in a lock, but if another process uses it right after it will panic with on the nil ref.  See https://golang.org/cl/35550 .

functions.name: TestIssue20160
functions.desc: TestIssue20160 attempts to test a short context life on a stmt Query.

functions.name: TestIssue20575
functions.desc: TestIssue20575 ensures the Rows from query does not block closing a transaction. Ensure Rows is closed while closing a transaction.

functions.name: TestIssue20622
functions.desc: TestIssue20622 tests closing the transaction before rows is closed, requires the race detector to fail.

functions.name: TestIssue2542Deadlock
functions.desc: Tests fix for issue 2542, that we release a lock when querying on a closed connection.

functions.name: TestIssue6651
functions.desc: Test issue 6651

functions.name: TestManyErrBadConn
functions.desc: Test cases where there's more than maxBadConnRetries bad connections in the pool (issue 8834)

functions.name: TestMaxOpenConnsOnBusy
functions.desc: Issue 9453: tests that SetMaxOpenConns can be lowered at runtime and affects the subsequent release of connections.

functions.name: TestNullByteSlice
functions.desc: Tests fix for issue 2788, that we bind nil to a []byte if the value in the column is sql null

functions.name: TestPendingConnsAfterErr
functions.desc: Issue 10886: tests that all connection attempts return when more than DB.maxOpen connections are in flight and the first DB.maxOpen fail.

functions.name: TestQueryContext
functions.desc: TestQueryContext tests canceling the context while scanning the rows.

functions.name: TestQueryContextWait
functions.desc: TestQueryContextWait ensures that rows and all internal statements are closed when a query context is closed during execution.

functions.name: TestQueryExecContextOnly
functions.desc: TestQueryExecContextOnly ensures drivers only need to implement QueryContext and ExecContext methods.

functions.name: TestQueryRowNilScanDest
functions.desc: golang.org/issue/4859

functions.name: TestRawBytesAllocs
functions.desc: Tests that assigning to RawBytes doesn't allocate (and also works).

functions.name: TestRawBytesReuse
functions.desc: Issue #65201.  If a RawBytes is reused across multiple queries, subsequent queries shouldn't overwrite driver-owned memory from previous queries.

functions.name: TestRowsCloseOrder
functions.desc: golang.org/issue/5283: don't release the Rows' connection in Close before calling Stmt.Close.

functions.name: TestRowsScanProperlyWrapsErrors
functions.desc: Issue 38099: Ensure that Rows.Scan properly wraps underlying errors.

functions.name: TestSimultaneousQueries
functions.desc: Issue 3857 This used to deadlock.

functions.name: TestStatementClose
functions.desc: golang.org/issue/12798

functions.name: TestStatementQueryRowConcurrent
functions.desc: golang.org/issue/3734

functions.name: TestStmtCloseDeps
functions.desc: golang.org/issue/5323

functions.name: TestTxCannotCommitAfterRollback
functions.desc: Issue 34775: Ensure that a Tx cannot commit after a rollback.

functions.name: TestTxContextWait
functions.desc: TestTxContextWait tests the transaction behavior when the tx context is canceled during execution of the query.

functions.name: TestTxContextWaitNoDiscard
functions.desc: TestTxContextWaitNoDiscard is the same as TestTxContextWait, but should not discard the final connection.

functions.name: TestTxEndBadConn
functions.desc: golang.org/issue/11264

functions.name: TestTxErrBadConn
functions.desc: Tests fix for issue 4433, that retries in Begin happen when conn.Begin() returns ErrBadConn

functions.name: TestTxQuery
functions.desc: Issue: https://golang.org/issue/2784 This test didn't fail before because we got lucky with the fakedb driver. It was failing, and now not, in github.com/bradfitz/go-sql-test

functions.name: TestTxStmtDeadlock
functions.desc: Issue 40985 transaction statement deadlock while context cancel.

functions.name: TestTxStmtFromTxStmtRePrepares
functions.desc: Test that tx.Stmt called with a statement already associated with tx as argument re-prepares the same statement again.

functions.name: TestTypedString
functions.desc: Issue 18101.

functions.name: TestUnsupportedOptions
functions.desc: TestUnsupportedOptions checks that the database fails when a driver that doesn't implement ConnBeginTx is used with non-default options and an un-cancellable context.

functions.name: TestUserDefinedBytes
functions.desc: https://golang.org/issues/13905

functions.name: callValuerValue
functions.desc: callValuerValue returns vr.Value(), with one exception: If vr.Value is an auto-generated method on a pointer type and the pointer is nil, it would panic at runtime in the panicwrap method. Treat it like nil instead. Issue 8415.  This is so people can implement driver.Value on value types and still use nil pointers to those types to mean nil/NULL, just like string/*string.  This function is mirrored in the database/sql/driver package.

functions.name: convertAssign
functions.desc: convertAssign is the same as convertAssignRows, but without the optional rows argument.  convertAssign should be an internal detail, but widely used packages access it using linkname. Notable members of the hall of shame include:   - ariga.io/entcache  Do not remove or change the type signature. See go.dev/issue/67401.

functions.name: convertAssignRows
functions.desc: convertAssignRows copies to dest the value in src, converting it if possible. An error is returned if the copy would result in loss of information. dest should be a pointer type. If rows is passed in, the rows will be used as the parent for any cursor values converted from a driver.Rows to a *Rows.

functions.name: defaultCheckNamedValue
functions.desc: defaultCheckNamedValue wraps the default ColumnConverter to have the same function signature as the CheckNamedValue in the driver.NamedValueChecker interface.

functions.name: driverArgsConnLocked
functions.desc: driverArgsConnLocked converts arguments from callers of Stmt.Exec and Stmt.Query into driver Values.  The statement ds may be nil, if no statement is available.  ci must be locked.

functions.name: numPrepares
functions.desc: numPrepares assumes that db has exactly 1 idle conn and returns its count of calls to Prepare

functions.name: setStrictFakeConnClose
functions.desc: setStrictFakeConnClose sets the t to Errorf on when fakeConn.Close fails to close. If nil, the check is disabled.

functions.name: testContextCancelDuringRawBytesScan
functions.desc: From go.dev/issue/60304

functions.name: testUseConns
functions.desc: testUseConns uses count concurrent connections with 1 nanosecond apart. Returns the returnedAt time of the final connection.

functions.name: waitForFree
functions.desc: waitForFree checks db.numFreeConns until either it equals want or the maxWait time elapses.

functions.name: withLock
functions.desc: withLock runs while holding lk.

functions.name: DatabaseTypeName
functions.desc: DatabaseTypeName returns the database system name of the column type. If an empty string is returned, then the driver type name is not supported. Consult your driver documentation for a list of driver data types. [ColumnType.Length] specifiers are not included. Common type names include "VARCHAR", "TEXT", "NVARCHAR", "DECIMAL", "BOOL", "INT", and "BIGINT".

functions.name: DecimalSize
functions.desc: DecimalSize returns the scale and precision of a decimal type. If not applicable or if not supported ok is false.

functions.name: Length
functions.desc: Length returns the column type length for variable length column types such as text and binary field types. If the type length is unbounded the value will be [math.MaxInt64] (any database limits will still apply). If the column type is not variable length, such as an int, or if not supported by the driver ok is false.

functions.name: Name
functions.desc: Name returns the name or alias of the column.

functions.name: Nullable
functions.desc: Nullable reports whether the column may be null. If a driver does not support this property ok will be false.

functions.name: ScanType
functions.desc: ScanType returns a Go type suitable for scanning into using [Rows.Scan]. If a driver does not support this property ScanType will return the type of an empty interface.

functions.name: BeginTx
functions.desc: BeginTx starts a transaction.  The provided context is used until the transaction is committed or rolled back. If the context is canceled, the sql package will roll back the transaction. [Tx.Commit] will return an error if the context provided to BeginTx is canceled.  The provided [TxOptions] is optional and may be nil if defaults should be used. If a non-default isolation level is used that the driver doesn't support, an error will be returned.

functions.name: Close
functions.desc: Close returns the connection to the connection pool. All operations after a Close will return with [ErrConnDone]. Close is safe to call concurrently with other operations and will block until all other operations finish. It may be useful to first cancel any used context and then call close directly after.

functions.name: ExecContext
functions.desc: ExecContext executes a query without returning any rows. The args are for any placeholder parameters in the query.

functions.name: PingContext
functions.desc: PingContext verifies the connection to the database is still alive.

functions.name: PrepareContext
functions.desc: PrepareContext creates a prepared statement for later queries or executions. Multiple queries or executions may be run concurrently from the returned statement. The caller must call the statement's [*Stmt.Close] method when the statement is no longer needed.  The provided context is used for the preparation of the statement, not for the execution of the statement.

functions.name: QueryContext
functions.desc: QueryContext executes a query that returns rows, typically a SELECT. The args are for any placeholder parameters in the query.

functions.name: QueryRowContext
functions.desc: QueryRowContext executes a query that is expected to return at most one row. QueryRowContext always returns a non-nil value. Errors are deferred until the [*Row.Scan] method is called. If the query selects no rows, the [*Row.Scan] will return [ErrNoRows]. Otherwise, the [*Row.Scan] scans the first selected row and discards the rest.

functions.name: Raw
functions.desc: Raw executes f exposing the underlying driver connection for the duration of f. The driverConn must not be used outside of f.  Once f returns and err is not [driver.ErrBadConn], the [Conn] will continue to be usable until [Conn.Close] is called.

functions.name: closemuRUnlockCondReleaseConn
functions.desc: closemuRUnlockCondReleaseConn read unlocks closemu as the sql operation is done with the dc.

functions.name: grabConn
functions.desc: grabConn takes a context to implement stmtConnGrabber but the context is not used.

functions.name: Begin
functions.desc: Begin starts a transaction. The default isolation level is dependent on the driver.  Begin uses [context.Background] internally; to specify the context, use [DB.BeginTx].

functions.name: BeginTx
functions.desc: BeginTx starts a transaction.  The provided context is used until the transaction is committed or rolled back. If the context is canceled, the sql package will roll back the transaction. [Tx.Commit] will return an error if the context provided to BeginTx is canceled.  The provided [TxOptions] is optional and may be nil if defaults should be used. If a non-default isolation level is used that the driver doesn't support, an error will be returned.

functions.name: Close
functions.desc: Close closes the database and prevents new queries from starting. Close then waits for all queries that have started processing on the server to finish.  It is rare to Close a [DB], as the [DB] handle is meant to be long-lived and shared between many goroutines.

functions.name: Conn
functions.desc: Conn returns a single connection by either opening a new connection or returning an existing connection from the connection pool. Conn will block until either a connection is returned or ctx is canceled. Queries run on the same Conn will be run in the same database session.  Every Conn must be returned to the database pool after use by calling [Conn.Close].

functions.name: Driver
functions.desc: Driver returns the database's underlying driver.

functions.name: Exec
functions.desc: Exec executes a query without returning any rows. The args are for any placeholder parameters in the query.  Exec uses [context.Background] internally; to specify the context, use [DB.ExecContext].

functions.name: ExecContext
functions.desc: ExecContext executes a query without returning any rows. The args are for any placeholder parameters in the query.

functions.name: Ping
functions.desc: Ping verifies a connection to the database is still alive, establishing a connection if necessary.  Ping uses [context.Background] internally; to specify the context, use [DB.PingContext].

functions.name: PingContext
functions.desc: PingContext verifies a connection to the database is still alive, establishing a connection if necessary.

functions.name: Prepare
functions.desc: Prepare creates a prepared statement for later queries or executions. Multiple queries or executions may be run concurrently from the returned statement. The caller must call the statement's [*Stmt.Close] method when the statement is no longer needed.  Prepare uses [context.Background] internally; to specify the context, use [DB.PrepareContext].

functions.name: PrepareContext
functions.desc: PrepareContext creates a prepared statement for later queries or executions. Multiple queries or executions may be run concurrently from the returned statement. The caller must call the statement's [*Stmt.Close] method when the statement is no longer needed.  The provided context is used for the preparation of the statement, not for the execution of the statement.

functions.name: Query
functions.desc: Query executes a query that returns rows, typically a SELECT. The args are for any placeholder parameters in the query.  Query uses [context.Background] internally; to specify the context, use [DB.QueryContext].

functions.name: QueryContext
functions.desc: QueryContext executes a query that returns rows, typically a SELECT. The args are for any placeholder parameters in the query.

functions.name: QueryRow
functions.desc: QueryRow executes a query that is expected to return at most one row. QueryRow always returns a non-nil value. Errors are deferred until [Row]'s Scan method is called. If the query selects no rows, the [*Row.Scan] will return [ErrNoRows]. Otherwise, [*Row.Scan] scans the first selected row and discards the rest.  QueryRow uses [context.Background] internally; to specify the context, use [DB.QueryRowContext].

functions.name: QueryRowContext
functions.desc: QueryRowContext executes a query that is expected to return at most one row. QueryRowContext always returns a non-nil value. Errors are deferred until [Row]'s Scan method is called. If the query selects no rows, the [*Row.Scan] will return [ErrNoRows]. Otherwise, [*Row.Scan] scans the first selected row and discards the rest.

functions.name: SetConnMaxIdleTime
functions.desc: SetConnMaxIdleTime sets the maximum amount of time a connection may be idle.  Expired connections may be closed lazily before reuse.  If d <= 0, connections are not closed due to a connection's idle time.

functions.name: SetConnMaxLifetime
functions.desc: SetConnMaxLifetime sets the maximum amount of time a connection may be reused.  Expired connections may be closed lazily before reuse.  If d <= 0, connections are not closed due to a connection's age.

functions.name: SetMaxIdleConns
functions.desc: SetMaxIdleConns sets the maximum number of connections in the idle connection pool.  If MaxOpenConns is greater than 0 but less than the new MaxIdleConns, then the new MaxIdleConns will be reduced to match the MaxOpenConns limit.  If n <= 0, no idle connections are retained.  The default max idle connections is currently 2. This may change in a future release.

functions.name: SetMaxOpenConns
functions.desc: SetMaxOpenConns sets the maximum number of open connections to the database.  If MaxIdleConns is greater than 0 and the new MaxOpenConns is less than MaxIdleConns, then MaxIdleConns will be reduced to match the new MaxOpenConns limit.  If n <= 0, then there is no limit on the number of open connections. The default is 0 (unlimited).

functions.name: Stats
functions.desc: Stats returns database statistics.

functions.name: addDep
functions.desc: addDep notes that x now depends on dep, and x's finalClose won't be called until all of x's dependencies are removed with removeDep.

functions.name: beginDC
functions.desc: beginDC starts a transaction. The provided dc must be valid and ready to use.

functions.name: clearAllConns
functions.desc: clearAllConns closes all connections in db.

functions.name: conn
functions.desc: conn returns a newly-opened or cached *driverConn.

functions.name: connectionCleanerRunLocked
functions.desc: connectionCleanerRunLocked removes connections that should be closed from freeConn and returns them along side an updated duration to the next check if a quicker check is required to ensure connections are checked appropriately.

functions.name: connectionOpener
functions.desc: Runs in a separate goroutine, opens new connections when requested.

functions.name: maybeOpenNewConnections
functions.desc: Assumes db.mu is locked. If there are connRequests and the connection limit hasn't been reached, then tell the connectionOpener to open new connections.

functions.name: noteUnusedDriverStatement
functions.desc: noteUnusedDriverStatement notes that ds is no longer used and should be closed whenever possible (when c is next not in use), unless c is already closed.

functions.name: numDepsPoll
functions.desc: Dependencies are closed via a goroutine, so this polls waiting for numDeps to fall to want, waiting up to nearly the test's deadline.

functions.name: openNewConnection
functions.desc: Open one new connection

functions.name: prepareDC
functions.desc: prepareDC prepares a query on the driverConn and calls release before returning. When cg == nil it implies that a connection pool is used, and when cg != nil only a single driver connection is used.

functions.name: putConn
functions.desc: putConn adds a connection to the db's free pool. err is optionally the last error that occurred on this connection.

functions.name: putConnDBLocked
functions.desc: Satisfy a connRequest or put the driverConn in the idle pool and return true or return false. putConnDBLocked will satisfy a connRequest if there is one, or it will return the *driverConn to the freeConn list if err == nil and the idle connection limit will not be exceeded. If err != nil, the value of dc is ignored. If err == nil, then dc must not equal nil. If a connRequest was fulfilled or the *driverConn was placed in the freeConn list, then true is returned, otherwise false is returned.

functions.name: queryDC
functions.desc: queryDC executes a query on the given connection. The connection gets released by the releaseConn function. The ctx context is from a query method and the txctx context is from an optional transaction context.

functions.name: removeDep
functions.desc: removeDep notes that x no longer depends on dep. If x still has dependencies, nil is returned. If x no longer has any dependencies, its finalClose method will be called and its error value will be returned.

functions.name: startCleanerLocked
functions.desc: startCleanerLocked starts connectionCleaner if needed.

functions.name: String
functions.desc: String returns the name of the transaction isolation level.
