functions.desc: startTheWorld undoes the effects of stopTheWorld.  w must be the worldStop returned by stopTheWorld.

functions.name: startTheWorldGC
functions.desc: startTheWorldGC undoes the effects of stopTheWorldGC.  w must be the worldStop returned by stopTheWorld.

functions.name: startTheWorldWithSema
functions.desc: reason is the same STW reason passed to stopTheWorld. start is the start time returned by stopTheWorld.  now is the current time; prefer to pass 0 to capture a fresh timestamp.  stattTheWorldWithSema returns now.

functions.name: startlockedm
functions.desc: Schedules the locked m to run the locked gp. May run during STW, so write barriers are not allowed.

functions.name: startm
functions.desc: Schedules some M to run the p (creates an M if necessary). If p==nil, tries to get an idle P, if no idle P's does nothing. May run with m.p==nil, so write barriers are not allowed. If spinning is set, the caller has incremented nmspinning and must provide a P. startm will set m.spinning in the newly started M.  Callers passing a non-nil P must call from a non-preemptible context. See comment on acquirem below.  Argument lockheld indicates whether the caller already acquired the scheduler lock. Callers holding the lock when making the call must pass true. The lock might be temporarily dropped, but will be reacquired before returning.  Must not have write barriers because this may be called without a P.

functions.name: startpanic_m
functions.desc: startpanic_m prepares for an unrecoverable panic.  It returns true if panic messages should be printed, or false if the runtime is in bad shape and should just print stacks.  It must not have write barriers even though the write barrier explicitly ignores writes once dying > 0. Write barriers still assume that g.m.p != nil, and this function may not have P in some contexts (e.g. a panic in a signal handler for a signal sent to an M with no P).

functions.name: stdcall
functions.desc: Calling stdcall on os stack. May run during STW, so write barriers are not allowed.

functions.name: stdcall_no_g
functions.desc: stdcall_no_g calls asmstdcall on os stack without using g.

functions.name: stealWork
functions.desc: stealWork attempts to steal a runnable goroutine or timer from any P.  If newWork is true, new work may have been readied.  If now is not 0 it is the current time. stealWork returns the passed time or the current time if now was passed as 0.

functions.name: step
functions.desc: step advances to the next pc, value pair in the encoded table.

functions.name: stopTimer
functions.desc: stopTimer stops a timer. It reports whether t was stopped before being run.

functions.name: stoplockedm
functions.desc: Stops execution of the current m that is locked to a g until the g is runnable again. Returns with acquired P.

functions.name: stopm
functions.desc: Stops execution of the current m until new work is available. Returns with acquired P.

functions.name: storeRegArgs
functions.desc: storeRegArgs sets up argument registers in the signal context state from an abi.RegArgs.  Both src and dst must be non-nil.

functions.name: strhash
functions.desc: strhash should be an internal detail, but widely used packages access it using linkname. Notable members of the hall of shame include:   - github.com/aristanetworks/goarista   - github.com/bytedance/sonic   - github.com/bytedance/go-tagexpr/v2   - github.com/cloudwego/dynamicgo   - github.com/v2fly/v2ray-core/v5  Do not remove or change the type signature. See go.dev/issue/67401.

functions.name: stringDataOnStack
functions.desc: stringDataOnStack reports whether the string's data is stored on the current goroutine's stack.

functions.name: stringHash
functions.desc: Testing adapters for hash quality tests (see hash_test.go)  stringHash should be an internal detail, but widely used packages access it using linkname. Notable members of the hall of shame include:   - github.com/k14s/starlark-go  Do not remove or change the type signature. See go.dev/issue/67401.

functions.name: subtract1
functions.desc: subtract1 returns the byte pointer p-1.  nosplit because it is used during write barriers and must not be preempted.

functions.name: subtractb
functions.desc: subtractb returns the byte pointer p-n.

functions.name: sweepone
functions.desc: sweepone sweeps some unswept heap span and returns the number of pages returned to the heap, or ^uintptr(0) if there was nothing to sweep.

functions.name: switchToCrashStack
functions.desc: Switch to crashstack and call fn, with special handling of concurrent and recursive cases.  Nosplit as it is called in a bad stack condition (we know morestack would fail).

functions.name: sync_runtime_Semacquire
functions.desc: sync_runtime_Semacquire should be an internal detail, but widely used packages access it using linkname. Notable members of the hall of shame include:   - gvisor.dev/gvisor   - github.com/sagernet/gvisor  Do not remove or change the type signature. See go.dev/issue/67401.

functions.name: sync_runtime_Semrelease
functions.desc: sync_runtime_Semrelease should be an internal detail, but widely used packages access it using linkname. Notable members of the hall of shame include:   - gvisor.dev/gvisor   - github.com/sagernet/gvisor  Do not remove or change the type signature. See go.dev/issue/67401.

functions.name: sync_runtime_canSpin
functions.desc: Active spinning for sync.Mutex.  sync_runtime_canSpin should be an internal detail, but widely used packages access it using linkname. Notable members of the hall of shame include:   - github.com/livekit/protocol   - github.com/sagernet/gvisor   - gvisor.dev/gvisor  Do not remove or change the type signature. See go.dev/issue/67401.

functions.name: sync_runtime_doSpin
functions.desc: sync_runtime_doSpin should be an internal detail, but widely used packages access it using linkname. Notable members of the hall of shame include:   - github.com/livekit/protocol   - github.com/sagernet/gvisor   - gvisor.dev/gvisor  Do not remove or change the type signature. See go.dev/issue/67401.

functions.name: sync_runtime_registerPoolCleanup
functions.desc: sync_runtime_registerPoolCleanup should be an internal detail, but widely used packages access it using linkname. Notable members of the hall of shame include:   - github.com/bytedance/gopkg   - github.com/songzhibin97/gkit  Do not remove or change the type signature. See go.dev/issue/67401.

functions.name: syncadjustsudogs
functions.desc: syncadjustsudogs adjusts gp's sudogs and copies the part of gp's stack they refer to while synchronizing with concurrent channel operations. It returns the number of bytes of stack copied.

functions.name: synctest_associate
functions.desc: synctest_associate associates p with the current bubble. It returns false if p is already associated with a different bubble.

functions.name: synctest_disassociate
functions.desc: synctest_disassociate disassociates p from its bubble.

functions.name: synctest_isAssociated
functions.desc: synctest_isAssociated reports whether p is associated with the current bubble.

functions.name: sysAlloc
functions.desc: sysAlloc transitions an OS-chosen region of memory from None to Ready. More specifically, it obtains a large chunk of zeroed memory from the operating system, typically on the order of a hundred kilobytes or a megabyte. This memory is always immediately available for use.  sysStat must be non-nil.  Don't split the stack as this function may be invoked without a valid G, which prevents us from allocating more stack.

functions.name: sysAllocOS
functions.desc: Don't split the stack as this function may be invoked without a valid G, which prevents us from allocating more stack.

functions.name: sysFault
functions.desc: sysFault transitions a memory region from Ready to Reserved. It marks a region such that it will always fault if accessed. Used only for debugging the runtime.  TODO(mknyszek): Currently it's true that all uses of sysFault transition memory from Ready to Reserved, but this may not be true in the future since on every platform the operation is much more general than that. If a transition from Prepared is ever introduced, create a new function that elides the Ready state accounting.

functions.name: sysFree
functions.desc: sysFree transitions a memory region from any state to None. Therefore, it returns memory unconditionally. It is used if an out-of-memory error has been detected midway through an allocation or to carve out an aligned section of the address space. It is okay if sysFree is a no-op only if sysReserve always returns a memory region aligned to the heap allocator's alignment restrictions.  sysStat must be non-nil.  Don't split the stack as this function may be invoked without a valid G, which prevents us from allocating more stack.

functions.name: sysFreeOS
functions.desc: Don't split the stack as this function may be invoked without a valid G, which prevents us from allocating more stack.

functions.name: sysHugePage
functions.desc: sysHugePage does not transition memory regions, but instead provides a hint to the OS that it would be more efficient to back this memory region with pages of a larger size transparently.

functions.name: sysHugePageCollapse
functions.desc: sysHugePageCollapse attempts to immediately back the provided memory region with huge pages. It is best-effort and may fail silently.

functions.name: sysMap
functions.desc: sysMap transitions a memory region from Reserved to Prepared. It ensures the memory region can be efficiently transitioned to Ready.  sysStat must be non-nil.

functions.name: sysMmap
functions.desc: sysMmap calls the mmap system call. It is implemented in assembly.

functions.name: sysMunmap
functions.desc: sysMunmap calls the munmap system call. It is implemented in assembly.

functions.name: sysNoHugePage
functions.desc: sysNoHugePage does not transition memory regions, but instead provides a hint to the OS that it would be less efficient to back this memory region with pages of a larger size transparently.

functions.name: sysReserve
functions.desc: sysReserve transitions a memory region from None to Reserved. It reserves address space in such a way that it would cause a fatal fault upon access (either via permissions or not committing the memory). Such a reservation is thus never backed by physical memory.  If the pointer passed to it is non-nil, the caller wants the reservation there, but sysReserve can still choose another location if that one is unavailable.  NOTE: sysReserve returns OS-aligned memory, but the heap allocator may use larger alignment, so the caller must be careful to realign the memory obtained by sysReserve.

functions.name: sysReserveAligned
functions.desc: sysReserveAligned is like sysReserve, but the returned pointer is aligned to align bytes. It may reserve either n or n+align bytes, so it returns the size that was reserved.

functions.name: sysSigaction
functions.desc: sysSigaction calls the rt_sigaction system call.

functions.name: sysUnused
functions.desc: sysUnused transitions a memory region from Ready to Prepared. It notifies the operating system that the physical pages backing this memory region are no longer needed and can be reused for other purposes. The contents of a sysUnused memory region are considered forfeit and the region must not be accessed again until sysUsed is called.

functions.name: sysUsed
functions.desc: sysUsed transitions a memory region from Prepared to Ready. It notifies the operating system that the memory region is needed and ensures that the region may be safely accessed. This is typically a no-op on systems that don't have an explicit commit step and hard over-commit limits, but is critical on Windows, for example.  This operation is idempotent for memory already in the Prepared state, so it is safe to refer, with v and n, to a range of memory that includes both Prepared and Ready memory. However, the caller must provide the exact amount of Prepared memory for accounting purposes.

functions.name: syscall_RawSyscall
functions.desc: This is syscall.RawSyscall, it exists to satisfy some build dependency, but it doesn't work.  This is exported via linkname to assembly in the syscall package.

functions.name: syscall_Syscall
functions.desc: Syscall is needed because some packages (like net) need it too. The best way is to return EINVAL and let Golang handles its failure If the syscall can't fail, this function can redirect it to a real syscall.  This is exported via linkname to assembly in the syscall package.

functions.name: syscall_cgocaller
functions.desc: wrapper for syscall package to call cgocall for libc (cgo) calls.

functions.name: syscall_close
functions.desc: like close, but must not split stack, for forkx.

functions.name: syscall_closeFD
functions.desc: like close, but must not split stack, for fork.

functions.name: syscall_exit
functions.desc: like exit, but must not split stack, for fork.

functions.name: syscall_getprocaddress
functions.desc: golang.org/x/sys linknames syscall.getprocaddress (in addition to standard package syscall). Do not remove or change the type signature.

functions.name: syscall_loadlibrary
functions.desc: golang.org/x/sys linknames syscall.loadlibrary (in addition to standard package syscall). Do not remove or change the type signature.

functions.name: syscall_rawSyscall
functions.desc: golang.org/x/sys linknames syscall_rawSyscall (in addition to standard package syscall). Do not remove or change the type signature.

functions.name: syscall_rawSyscall6
functions.desc: golang.org/x/sys linknames syscall_rawSyscall6 (in addition to standard package syscall). Do not remove or change the type signature.

functions.name: syscall_rawsyscall
functions.desc: This is syscall.RawSyscall, it exists to satisfy some build dependency, but it doesn't work.

functions.name: syscall_rawsyscall6
functions.desc: This is syscall.RawSyscall6, it exists to avoid a linker error because syscall.RawSyscall6 is already declared. See golang.org/issue/24357

functions.name: syscall_runtime_AfterExec
functions.desc: Called from syscall package after Exec.

functions.name: syscall_runtime_AfterFork
functions.desc: Called from syscall package after fork in parent.  syscall_runtime_AfterFork is for package syscall, but widely used packages access it using linkname. Notable members of the hall of shame include:   - gvisor.dev/gvisor  Do not remove or change the type signature. See go.dev/issue/67401.

functions.name: syscall_runtime_AfterForkInChild
functions.desc: Called from syscall package after fork in child. It resets non-sigignored signals to the default handler, and restores the signal mask in preparation for the exec.  Because this might be called during a vfork, and therefore may be temporarily sharing address space with the parent process, this must not change any global variables or calling into C code that may do so.  syscall_runtime_AfterForkInChild is for package syscall, but widely used packages access it using linkname. Notable members of the hall of shame include:   - gvisor.dev/gvisor  Do not remove or change the type signature. See go.dev/issue/67401.

functions.name: syscall_runtime_BeforeExec
functions.desc: Called from syscall package before Exec.

functions.name: syscall_runtime_BeforeFork
functions.desc: Called from syscall package before fork.  syscall_runtime_BeforeFork is for package syscall, but widely used packages access it using linkname. Notable members of the hall of shame include:   - gvisor.dev/gvisor  Do not remove or change the type signature. See go.dev/issue/67401.

functions.name: syscall_runtime_doAllThreadsSyscall
functions.desc: syscall_runtime_doAllThreadsSyscall and executes a specified system call on all Ms.  The system call is expected to succeed and return the same value on every thread. If any threads do not match, the runtime throws.

functions.name: syscall_syscall
functions.desc: golang.org/x/sys linknames syscall_syscall (in addition to standard package syscall). Do not remove or change the type signature.

functions.name: syscall_syscall10
functions.desc: golang.org/x/sys linknames syscall.syscall10 (in addition to standard package syscall). Do not remove or change the type signature.

functions.name: syscall_syscall6
functions.desc: golang.org/x/sys linknames syscall.syscall6 (in addition to standard package syscall). Do not remove or change the type signature.  syscall.syscall6 is meant for package syscall (and x/sys), but widely used packages access it using linkname. Notable members of the hall of shame include:   - github.com/tetratelabs/wazero  See go.dev/issue/67401.

functions.name: syscall_syscall9
functions.desc: golang.org/x/sys linknames syscall.syscall9 (in addition to standard package syscall). Do not remove or change the type signature.

functions.name: syscall_syscallPtr
functions.desc: golang.org/x/sys linknames syscall.syscallPtr (in addition to standard package syscall). Do not remove or change the type signature.

functions.name: sysctlnametomib
functions.desc: sysctlnametomib fill mib with dynamically assigned sysctl entries of name, return count of effected mib slots, return 0 on error.

functions.name: sysmon
functions.desc: Always runs without a P, so write barriers are not allowed.

functions.name: systemstack
functions.desc: systemstack runs fn on a system stack. If systemstack is called from the per-OS-thread (g0) stack, or if systemstack is called from the signal handling (gsignal) stack, systemstack calls fn directly and returns. Otherwise, systemstack is being called from the limited stack of an ordinary goroutine. In this case, systemstack switches to the per-OS-thread stack, calls fn, and switches back. It is common to use a func literal as the argument, in order to share inputs and outputs with the code around the call to system stack:  	... set up y ... 	systemstack(func() { 		x = bigcall(y) 	}) 	... use x ...

functions.name: sysvicall1Err
functions.desc: sysvicall1Err returns both the system call result and the errno value. This is used by sysvicall1 and pipe.

functions.name: sysvicall2Err
functions.desc: sysvicall2Err returns both the system call result and the errno value. This is used by sysvicall2 and pipe2.

functions.name: sysvicall3Err
functions.desc: sysvicall3Err returns both the system call result and the errno value. This is used by sysvicall3 and write1.

functions.name: templateThread
functions.desc: templateThread is a thread in a known-good state that exists solely to start new threads in known-good states when the calling thread may not be in a good state.  Many programs never need this, so templateThread is started lazily when we first enter a state that might lead to running on a thread in an unknown state.  templateThread runs on an M without a P, so it must not have write barriers.

functions.name: threadCreateProfileInternal
functions.desc: threadCreateProfileInternal returns the number of records n in the profile. If there are less than size records, copyFn is invoked for each record, and ok returns true.

functions.name: throw
functions.desc: throw triggers a fatal error that dumps a stack trace and exits.  throw should be used for runtime-internal fatal errors where Go itself, rather than user code, may be at fault for the failure.  throw should be an internal detail, but widely used packages access it using linkname. Notable members of the hall of shame include:   - github.com/bytedance/sonic   - github.com/cockroachdb/pebble   - github.com/dgraph-io/ristretto   - github.com/outcaste-io/ristretto   - github.com/pingcap/br   - gvisor.dev/gvisor   - github.com/sagernet/gvisor  Do not remove or change the type signature. See go.dev/issue/67401.

functions.name: ticksPerSecond
functions.desc: ticksPerSecond returns a conversion rate between the cputicks clock and the nanotime clock.  Note: Clocks are hard. Using this as an actual conversion rate for timestamps is ill-advised and should be avoided when possible. Use only for durations, where a tiny error term isn't going to make a meaningful difference in even a 1ms duration. If an accurate timestamp is needed, use nanotime instead. (The entire Windows platform is a broad exception to this rule, where nanotime produces timestamps on such a coarse granularity that the error from this conversion is actually preferable.)  The strategy for computing the conversion rate is to write down nanotime and cputicks as early in process startup as possible. From then, we just need to wait until we get values from nanotime that we can use (some platforms have a really coarse system time granularity). We require some amount of time to pass to ensure that the conversion rate is fairly accurate in aggregate. But because we compute this rate lazily, there's a pretty good chance a decent amount of time has passed by the time we get here.  Must be called from a normal goroutine context (running regular goroutine with a P).  Called by runtime/pprof in addition to runtime code.  TODO(mknyszek): This doesn't account for things like CPU frequency scaling. Consider a more sophisticated and general approach in the future.

functions.name: timeHistogramMetricsBuckets
functions.desc: timeHistogramMetricsBuckets generates a slice of boundaries for the timeHistogram. These boundaries are represented in seconds, not nanoseconds like the timeHistogram represents durations.

functions.name: timeSleep
functions.desc: timeSleep puts the current goroutine to sleep for at least ns nanoseconds.

functions.name: timeSleepUntil
functions.desc: timeSleepUntil returns the time when the next timer should fire. Returns maxWhen if there are no timers. This is only called by sysmon and checkdead.

functions.name: time_now
functions.desc: Do not remove or change the type signature. See comment in timestub.go.

functions.name: timediv
functions.desc: Poor mans 64-bit division. This is a very special function, do not use it if you are not sure what you are doing. int64 division is lowered into _divv() call on 386, which does not fit into nosplit functions. Handles overflow in a time-specific manner. This keeps us within no-split stack limits on 32-bit processors.

functions.name: timerchandrain
functions.desc: timerchandrain removes all elements in channel c's buffer. It reports whether any elements were removed. Because it is only intended for timers, it does not handle waiting senders at all (all timer channels use non-blocking sends to fill the buffer).

functions.name: timesplit
functions.desc: timesplit returns u/1e9, u%1e9

functions.name: tlsinit
functions.desc: tlsinit allocates a thread-local storage slot for g.  It finds the first available slot using pthread_key_create and uses it as the offset value for runtime.tlsg.  This runs at startup on g0 stack, but before g is set, so it must not split stack (transitively). g is expected to be nil, so things (e.g. asmcgocall) will skip saving or reading g.

functions.name: tooManyOverflowBuckets
functions.desc: tooManyOverflowBuckets reports whether noverflow buckets is too many for a map with 1<<B buckets. Note that most of these overflow buckets must be in sparse use; if use was dense, then we'd have already triggered regular map growth.

functions.name: tophash
functions.desc: tophash calculates the tophash value for hash.

functions.name: traceAdvance
functions.desc: traceAdvance moves tracing to the next generation, and cleans up the current generation, ensuring that it's flushed out before returning. If stopTrace is true, it disables tracing altogether instead of advancing to the next generation.  traceAdvanceSema must not be held.  traceAdvance is called by runtime/trace and golang.org/x/exp/trace using linkname.

functions.name: traceAllocFreeEnabled
functions.desc: traceAllocFreeEnabled returns true if the trace is currently enabled and alloc/free events are also enabled.

functions.name: traceBufFlush
functions.desc: traceBufFlush flushes a trace buffer.  Must run on the system stack because trace.lock must be held.

functions.name: traceCPUFlush
functions.desc: traceCPUFlush flushes trace.cpuBuf[gen%2]. The caller must be certain that gen has completed and that there are no more writers to it.

functions.name: traceCPUSample
functions.desc: traceCPUSample writes a CPU profile sample stack to the execution tracer's profiling buffer. It is called from a signal handler, so is limited in what it can do. mp must be the thread that is currently stopped in a signal.

functions.name: traceClockUnitsPerSecond
functions.desc: traceClockUnitsPerSecond estimates the number of trace clock units per second that elapse.

functions.name: traceEnabled
functions.desc: traceEnabled returns true if the trace is currently enabled.

functions.name: traceExitedSyscall
functions.desc: traceExitedSyscall marks a goroutine as having exited the syscall slow path.

functions.name: traceExitingSyscall
functions.desc: traceExitingSyscall marks a goroutine as exiting the syscall slow path.  Must be paired with a traceExitedSyscall call.

functions.name: traceInitReadCPU
functions.desc: traceInitReadCPU initializes CPU profile -> tracer state for tracing.  Returns a profBuf for reading from.

functions.name: traceLockInit
functions.desc: traceLockInit initializes global trace locks.

functions.name: traceReadCPU
functions.desc: traceReadCPU attempts to read from the provided profBuf[gen%2] and write into the trace. Returns true if there might be more to read or false if the profBuf is closed or the caller should otherwise stop reading.  The caller is responsible for ensuring that gen does not change. Either the caller must be in a traceAcquire/traceRelease block, or must be calling with traceAdvanceSema held.  No more than one goroutine may be in traceReadCPU for the same profBuf at a time.  Must not run on the system stack because profBuf.read performs race operations.

functions.name: traceRegisterLabelsAndReasons
functions.desc: traceRegisterLabelsAndReasons re-registers mark worker labels and goroutine stop/block reasons in the string table for the provided generation. Note: the provided generation must not have started yet.

functions.name: traceRelease
functions.desc: traceRelease indicates that this M is done writing trace events.  nosplit because it's called on the syscall path when stack movement is forbidden.

functions.name: traceShuttingDown
functions.desc: traceShuttingDown returns true if the trace is currently shutting down.

functions.name: traceSnapshotMemory
functions.desc: traceSnapshotMemory takes a snapshot of all runtime memory that there are events for (heap spans, heap objects, goroutine stacks, etc.) and writes out events for them.  The world must be stopped and tracing must be enabled when this function is called.

functions.name: traceStack
functions.desc: traceStack captures a stack trace from a goroutine and registers it in the trace stack table. It then returns its unique ID. If gp == nil, then traceStack will attempt to use the current execution context.  skip controls the number of leaf frames to omit in order to hide tracer internals from stack traces, see CL 5523.  Avoid calling this function directly. Prefer traceEventWriter.stack.

functions.name: traceStartReadCPU
functions.desc: traceStartReadCPU creates a goroutine to start reading CPU profile data into an active trace.  traceAdvanceSema must be held.

functions.name: traceStopReadCPU
functions.desc: traceStopReadCPU blocks until the trace CPU reading goroutine exits.  traceAdvanceSema must be held, and tracing must be disabled.

functions.name: traceThreadDestroy
functions.desc: traceThreadDestroy is called when a thread is removed from sched.freem.  mp must not be able to emit trace events anymore.  sched.lock must be held to synchronize with traceAdvance.

functions.name: trace_userLog
functions.desc: trace_userLog emits a UserRegionBegin or UserRegionEnd event.

functions.name: trace_userRegion
functions.desc: trace_userRegion emits a UserRegionBegin or UserRegionEnd event, depending on mode (0 == Begin, 1 == End).  TODO(mknyszek): Just make this two functions.

functions.name: trace_userTaskCreate
functions.desc: trace_userTaskCreate emits a UserTaskCreate event.

functions.name: trace_userTaskEnd
functions.desc: trace_userTaskEnd emits a UserTaskEnd event.

functions.name: traceback2
functions.desc: traceback2 prints a stack trace starting at u. It skips the first "skip" logical frames, after which it prints at most "max" logical frames. It returns n, which is the number of logical frames skipped and printed, and lastN, which is the number of logical frames skipped or printed just in the physical frame that u references.

functions.name: tracebackHexdump
functions.desc: tracebackHexdump hexdumps part of stk around frame.sp and frame.fp for debugging purposes. If the address bad is included in the hexdumped range, it will mark it as well.

functions.name: tracebackPCs
functions.desc: tracebackPCs populates pcBuf with the return addresses for each frame from u and returns the number of PCs written to pcBuf. The returned PCs correspond to "logical frames" rather than "physical frames"; that is if A is inlined into B, this will still return a PCs for both A and B. This also includes PCs generated by the cgo unwinder, if one is registered.  If skip != 0, this skips this many logical frames.  Callers should set the unwindSilentErrors flag on u.

functions.name: tracebacktrap
functions.desc: tracebacktrap is like traceback but expects that the PC and SP were obtained from a trap, not from gp->sched or gp->syscallpc/gp->syscallsp or GetCallerPC/GetCallerSP. Because they are from a trap instead of from a saved pair, the initial PC must not be rewound to the previous instruction. (All the saved pairs record a PC that is a return address, so we rewind it into the CALL instruction.) If gp.m.libcall{g,pc,sp} information is available, it uses that information in preference to the pc/sp/lr passed in.

functions.name: tracefpunwindoff
functions.desc: tracefpunwindoff returns true if frame pointer unwinding for the tracer is disabled via GODEBUG or not supported by the architecture.

functions.name: tryDeferToSpanScan
functions.desc: tryQueueOnSpan tries to queue p on the span it points to, if it points to a small object span (gcUsesSpanQueue size).

functions.name: tryRecordGoroutineProfile
functions.desc: tryRecordGoroutineProfile ensures that gp1 has the appropriate representation in the current goroutine profile: either that it should not be profiled, or that a snapshot of its call stack and labels are now in the profile.

functions.name: tryRecordGoroutineProfileWB
functions.desc: tryRecordGoroutineProfileWB asserts that write barriers are allowed and calls tryRecordGoroutineProfile.

functions.name: tstart_stdcall
functions.desc: Function to be called by windows CreateThread to start new os thread.

functions.name: typeBitsBulkBarrier
functions.desc: typeBitsBulkBarrier executes a write barrier for every pointer that would be copied from [src, src+size) to [dst, dst+size) by a memmove using the type bitmap to locate those pointer slots.  The type typ must correspond exactly to [src, src+size) and [dst, dst+size). dst, src, and size must be pointer-aligned.  Must not be preempted because it typically runs right before memmove, and the GC must observe them as an atomic action.  Callers must perform cgo checks if goexperiment.CgoCheck2.

functions.name: typedmemclr
functions.desc: typedmemclr clears the typed memory at ptr with type typ. The memory at ptr must already be initialized (and hence in type-safe state). If the memory is being initialized for the first time, see memclrNoHeapPointers.  If the caller knows that typ has pointers, it can alternatively call memclrHasPointers.  TODO: A "go:nosplitrec" annotation would be perfect for this.

functions.name: typedmemmove
functions.desc: typedmemmove copies a value of type typ to dst from src. Must be nosplit, see #16026.  TODO: Perfect for go:nosplitrec since we can't have a safe point anywhere in the bulk barrier or memmove.  typedmemmove should be an internal detail, but widely used packages access it using linkname. Notable members of the hall of shame include:   - github.com/RomiChan/protobuf   - github.com/segmentio/encoding  Do not remove or change the type signature. See go.dev/issue/67401.

functions.name: typedslicecopy
functions.desc: typedslicecopy should be an internal detail, but widely used packages access it using linkname. Notable members of the hall of shame include:   - github.com/segmentio/encoding  Do not remove or change the type signature. See go.dev/issue/67401.

functions.name: typehash
functions.desc: typehash computes the hash of the object of type t at address p. h is the seed. This function is seldom used. Most maps use for hashing either fixed functions (e.g. f32hash) or compiler-generated functions (e.g. for a type like struct { x, y string }). This implementation is slower but more general and is used for hashing interface types (called from interhash or nilinterhash, above) or for hashing in maps generated by reflect.MapOf (reflect_typehash, below). Note: this function must match the compiler generated functions exactly. See issue 37716.  typehash should be an internal detail, but widely used packages access it using linkname. Notable members of the hall of shame include:   - github.com/puzpuzpuz/xsync/v2   - github.com/puzpuzpuz/xsync/v3  Do not remove or change the type signature. See go.dev/issue/67401.

functions.name: typelinksinit
functions.desc: typelinksinit scans the types from extra modules and builds the moduledata typemap used to de-duplicate type pointers.

functions.name: typesEqual
functions.desc: typesEqual reports whether two types are equal.  Everywhere in the runtime and reflect packages, it is assumed that there is exactly one *_type per Go type, so that pointer equality can be used to test if types are equal. There is one place that breaks this assumption: buildmode=shared. In this case a type can appear as two different pieces of memory. This is hidden from the runtime and reflect package by the per-module typemap built in typelinksinit. It uses typesEqual to map types from later modules back into earlier ones.  Only typelinksinit needs this function.

functions.name: udiv
functions.desc: Called from compiler-generated code; declared for go vet.

functions.name: unblockTimerChan
functions.desc: unblockTimerChan is called when a channel op that was blocked on c is no longer blocked. Every call to blockTimerChan must be paired with a call to unblockTimerChan. The caller holds the channel lock for c and possibly other channels. unblockTimerChan removes c from the timer heap when nothing is blocked on it anymore.

functions.name: unblocksig
functions.desc: unblocksig removes sig from the current thread's signal mask. This is nosplit and nowritebarrierrec because it is called from dieFromSignal, which can be called by sigfwdgo while running in the signal handler, on the signal stack, with no g available.

functions.name: unlock2
functions.desc: We might not be holding a p in this code.

functions.name: unlock2Wake
functions.desc: unlock2Wake updates the list of Ms waiting on l, waking an M if necessary.

functions.name: unlockWithRank
functions.desc: See comment on lockWithRank regarding stack splitting.

functions.name: unminit
functions.desc: Called from dropm to undo the effect of an minit.

functions.name: unminitSignals
functions.desc: unminitSignals is called from dropm, via unminit, to undo the effect of calling minit on a non-Go thread.

functions.name: unpackNetpollSource
functions.desc: unpackNetpollSource returns the source packed key.

functions.name: unreachableMethod
functions.desc: The linker redirects a reference of a method that it determined unreachable to a reference to this function, so it will throw if ever called.

functions.name: unsafeslice
functions.desc: Keep this code in sync with cmd/compile/internal/walk/builtin.go:walkUnsafeSlice

functions.name: unsafeslice64
functions.desc: Keep this code in sync with cmd/compile/internal/walk/builtin.go:walkUnsafeSlice

functions.name: unsafestring64
functions.desc: Keep this code in sync with cmd/compile/internal/walk/builtin.go:walkUnsafeString

functions.name: unsetenv_c
functions.desc: Update the C environment if cgo is loaded.

functions.name: userArenaChunkReserveBytes
functions.desc: userArenaChunkReserveBytes returns the amount of additional bytes to reserve for heap metadata.

functions.name: userArenaHeapBitsSetSliceType
functions.desc: userArenaHeapBitsSetSliceType is the equivalent of heapBitsSetType but for Go slice backing store values allocated in a user arena chunk. It sets up the heap bitmap for n consecutive values with type typ allocated at address ptr.

functions.name: userArenaHeapBitsSetType
functions.desc: userArenaHeapBitsSetType is the equivalent of heapSetType but for non-slice-backing-store Go values allocated in a user arena chunk. It sets up the type metadata for the value with type typ allocated at address ptr. base is the base address of the arena chunk.

functions.name: usesLibcall
functions.desc: usesLibcall indicates whether this runtime performs system calls via libcall.

functions.name: usplit
functions.desc: for testing

functions.name: usplitR0
functions.desc: Called from assembly only; declared for go vet.

functions.name: validSIGPROF
functions.desc: validSIGPROF compares this signal delivery's code against the signal sources that the profiler uses, returning whether the delivery should be processed. To be processed, a signal delivery from a known profiling mechanism should correspond to the best profiling mechanism available to this thread. Signals from other sources are always considered valid.

functions.name: values
functions.desc: values for implementing maps.values

functions.name: vgetrandom
functions.desc: This is exported for use in internal/syscall/unix as well as x/sys/unix.

functions.name: vgetrandomDestroy
functions.desc: Free vgetrandom state from the M (if any) prior to destroying the M.  This may allocate, so it must have a P.

functions.name: waitForSigusr1Callback
functions.desc: waitForSigusr1Callback is called from the signal handler during WaitForSigusr1. It must not have write barriers because there may not be a P.

functions.name: wakeNetPoller
functions.desc: wakeNetPoller wakes up the thread sleeping in the network poller if it isn't going to wake up before the when argument; or it wakes an idle P to service timers and the network poller if there isn't one already.

functions.name: wakep
functions.desc: Tries to add one more P to execute G's. Called when a G is made runnable (newproc, ready). Must be called with a P.  wakep should be an internal detail, but widely used packages access it using linkname. Notable members of the hall of shame include:   - gvisor.dev/gvisor  Do not remove or change the type signature. See go.dev/issue/67401.

functions.name: walltime
functions.desc: walltime should be an internal detail, but widely used packages access it using linkname. Notable members of the hall of shame include:   - gitee.com/quant1x/gox  Do not remove or change the type signature. See go.dev/issue/67401.

functions.name: wantAsyncPreempt
functions.desc: wantAsyncPreempt returns whether an asynchronous preemption is queued for gp.

functions.name: wbBufFlush
functions.desc: wbBufFlush flushes the current P's write barrier buffer to the GC workbufs.  This must not have write barriers because it is part of the write barrier implementation.  This and everything it calls must be nosplit because 1) the stack contains untyped slots from gcWriteBarrier and 2) there must not be a GC safe point between the write barrier test in the caller and flushing the buffer.  TODO: A "go:nosplitrec" annotation would be perfect for this.

functions.name: wbBufFlush1
functions.desc: wbBufFlush1 flushes p's write barrier buffer to the GC work queue.  This must not have write barriers because it is part of the write barrier implementation, so this may lead to infinite loops or buffer corruption.  This must be non-preemptible because it uses the P's workbuf.

functions.name: wbMove
functions.desc: wbMove performs the write barrier operations necessary before copying a region of memory from src to dst of type typ. Does not actually do the copying.

functions.name: wbZero
functions.desc: wbZero performs the write barrier operations necessary before zeroing a region of memory at address dst of type typ. Does not actually do the zeroing.

functions.name: winthrow
functions.desc: Always called on g0. gp is the G where the exception occurred.

functions.name: wintls
functions.desc: Init-time helper

functions.name: wirep
functions.desc: wirep is the first step of acquirep, which actually associates the current M to pp. This is broken out so we can disallow write barriers for this part, since we don't yet have a P.

functions.name: worldStarted
functions.desc: worldStarted that the world is starting.  Caller must hold worldsema.  nosplit to ensure it can be called in as many contexts as possible.

functions.name: worldStopped
functions.desc: worldStopped notes that the world is stopped.  Caller must hold worldsema.  nosplit to ensure it can be called in as many contexts as possible.

functions.name: write
functions.desc: write must be nosplit on Windows (see write1)

functions.name: write1
functions.desc: write1 calls the write system call. It returns a non-negative number of bytes written or a negative errno value.

functions.name: writeConsole
functions.desc: writeConsole writes bufLen bytes from buf to the console File. It returns the number of bytes written.

functions.name: writeConsoleUTF16
functions.desc: writeConsoleUTF16 is the dedicated windows calls that correctly prints to the console regardless of the current code page. Input is utf-16 code points. The handle must be a console handle.

functions.name: writeErrData
functions.desc: writeErrData is the common parts of writeErr{,Str}.

functions.name: writeErrStr
functions.desc: writeErrStr writes a string to descriptor 2. If SetCrashOutput(f) was called, it also writes to f.

functions.name: writeLogdHeader
functions.desc: writeLogdHeader populates the header and returns the length of the payload.

functions.name: Base
functions.desc: Base returns the virtual base address of the address range.

functions.name: Equals
functions.desc: Equals returns true if the two address ranges are exactly equal.

functions.name: Limit
functions.desc: Base returns the virtual address of the limit of the address range.

functions.name: Size
functions.desc: Size returns the size in bytes of the address range.

functions.name: contains
functions.desc: contains returns whether or not the range contains a given address.

functions.name: removeGreaterEqual
functions.desc: removeGreaterEqual removes all addresses in a greater than or equal to addr and returns the new range.

functions.name: size
functions.desc: size returns the size of the range represented in bytes.

functions.name: subtract
functions.desc: subtract takes the addrRange toPrune and cuts out any overlap with from, then returns the new range. subtract assumes that a and b either don't overlap at all, only overlap on one side, or are equal. If b is strictly contained in a, thus forcing a split, it will throw.

functions.name: takeFromBack
functions.desc: takeFromBack takes len bytes from the end of the address range, aligning the limit to align after subtracting len. On success, returns the aligned start of the region taken and true.

functions.name: takeFromFront
functions.desc: takeFromFront takes len bytes from the front of the address range, aligning the base to align first. On success, returns the aligned start of the region taken and true.

functions.name: Add
functions.desc: Add adds a new AddrRange to the AddrRanges.  The AddrRange must be mutable (i.e. created by NewAddrRanges), otherwise this method will throw.

functions.name: FindSucc
functions.desc: FindSucc returns the successor to base. See addrRanges.findSucc for more details.

functions.name: Ranges
functions.desc: Ranges returns a copy of the ranges described by the addrRanges.

functions.name: TotalBytes
functions.desc: TotalBytes returns the totalBytes field of the addrRanges.

functions.name: add
functions.desc: add inserts a new address range to a.  r must not overlap with any address range in a and r.size() must be > 0.

functions.name: cloneInto
functions.desc: cloneInto makes a deep clone of a's state into b, re-using b's ranges if able.

functions.name: contains
functions.desc: contains returns true if a covers the address addr.

functions.name: findAddrGreaterEqual
functions.desc: findAddrGreaterEqual returns the smallest address represented by a that is >= addr. Thus, if the address is represented by a, then it returns addr. The second return value indicates whether such an address exists for addr in a. That is, if addr is larger than any address known to a, the second return value will be false.

functions.name: findSucc
functions.desc: findSucc returns the first index in a such that addr is less than the base of the addrRange at that index.

functions.name: removeGreaterEqual
functions.desc: removeGreaterEqual removes the ranges of a which are above addr, and additionally splits any range containing addr.

functions.name: removeLast
functions.desc: removeLast removes and returns the highest-addressed contiguous range of a, or the last nBytes of that range, whichever is smaller. If a is empty, it returns an empty range.

functions.name: Stop
functions.desc: Stop cancels the cleanup call. Stop will have no effect if the cleanup call has already been queued for execution (because ptr became unreachable). To guarantee that Stop removes the cleanup function, the caller must ensure that the pointer that was passed to AddCleanup is reachable across the call to Stop.

functions.name: lr
functions.desc: 386 does not have link register, so this returns 0.

functions.name: set_fp
functions.desc: 386 does not have frame pointer register.

functions.name: Next
functions.desc: Next returns a [Frame] representing the next call frame in the slice of PC values. If it has already returned all call frames, Next returns a zero [Frame].  The more result indicates whether the next call to Next will return a valid [Frame]. It does not necessarily indicate whether this call returned one.  See the [Frames] example for idiomatic usage.

functions.name: Entry
functions.desc: Entry returns the entry address of the function.

functions.name: FileLine
functions.desc: FileLine returns the file name and line number of the source code corresponding to the program counter pc. The result will not be accurate if pc is not a program counter within f.

functions.name: Name
functions.desc: Name returns the name of the function.

functions.name: startLine
functions.desc: startLine returns the starting line number of the function. i.e., the line number of the func keyword.

functions.name: addIdleMarkWorker
functions.desc: addIdleMarkWorker attempts to add a new idle mark worker.  If this returns true, the caller must become an idle mark worker unless there's no background mark worker goroutines in the pool. This case is harmless because there are already background mark workers running. If this returns false, the caller must NOT become an idle mark worker.  nosplit because it may be called without a P.

functions.name: commit
functions.desc: commit recomputes all pacing parameters needed to derive the trigger and the heap goal. Namely, the gcPercent-based heap goal, and the amount of runway we want to give the GC this cycle.  This can be called any time. If GC is the in the middle of a concurrent phase, it will adjust the pacing of that phase.  isSweepDone should be the result of calling isSweepDone(), unless we're testing or we know we're executing during a GC cycle.  This depends on gcPercent, gcController.heapMarked, and gcController.heapLive. These must be up to date.  Callers must call gcControllerState.revise after calling this function if the GC is enabled.  mheap_.lock must be held or the world must be stopped.

functions.name: endCycle
functions.desc: endCycle computes the consMark estimate for the next cycle. userForced indicates whether the current GC cycle was forced by the application.

functions.name: enlistWorker
functions.desc: enlistWorker encourages another dedicated mark worker to start on another P if there are spare worker slots. It is used by putfull when more work is made available.  If goexperiment.GreenTeaGC, the caller must not hold a G's scan bit, otherwise this could cause a deadlock. This is already enforced by the static lock ranking.

functions.name: findRunnableGCWorker
functions.desc: findRunnableGCWorker returns a background mark worker for pp if it should be run. This must only be called when gcBlackenEnabled != 0.

functions.name: heapGoal
functions.desc: heapGoal returns the current heap goal.

functions.name: heapGoalInternal
functions.desc: heapGoalInternal is the implementation of heapGoal which returns additional information that is necessary for computing the trigger.  The returned minTrigger is always <= goal.

functions.name: markWorkerStop
functions.desc: markWorkerStop must be called whenever a mark worker stops executing.  It updates mark work accounting in the controller by a duration of work in nanoseconds and other bookkeeping.  Safe to execute at any time.

functions.name: memoryLimitHeapGoal
functions.desc: memoryLimitHeapGoal returns a heap goal derived from memoryLimit.

functions.name: needIdleMarkWorker
functions.desc: needIdleMarkWorker is a hint as to whether another idle mark worker is needed.  The caller must still call addIdleMarkWorker to become one. This is mainly useful for a quick check before an expensive operation.  nosplit because it may be called without a P.

functions.name: removeIdleMarkWorker
functions.desc: removeIdleMarkWorker must be called when a new idle mark worker stops executing.

functions.name: resetLive
functions.desc: resetLive sets up the controller state for the next mark phase after the end of the previous one. Must be called after endCycle and before commit, before the world is started.  The world must be stopped.

functions.name: revise
functions.desc: revise updates the assist ratio during the GC cycle to account for improved estimates. This should be called whenever gcController.heapScan, gcController.heapLive, or if any inputs to gcController.heapGoal are updated. It is safe to call concurrently, but it may race with other calls to revise.  The result of this race is that the two assist ratio values may not line up or may be stale. In practice this is OK because the assist ratio moves slowly throughout a GC cycle, and the assist ratio is a best-effort heuristic anyway. Furthermore, no part of the heuristic depends on the two assist ratio values being exact reciprocals of one another, since the two values are used to convert values from different sources.  The worst case result of this raciness is that we may miss a larger shift in the ratio (say, if we decide to pace more aggressively against the hard heap goal) but even this "hard goal" is best-effort (see #40460). The dedicated GC should ensure we don't exceed the hard goal by too much in the rare case we do exceed it.  It should only be called when gcBlackenEnabled != 0 (because this is when assists are enabled and the necessary statistics are available).

functions.name: setGCPercent
functions.desc: setGCPercent updates gcPercent. commit must be called after. Returns the old value of gcPercent.  The world must be stopped, or mheap_.lock must be held.

functions.name: setMaxIdleMarkWorkers
functions.desc: setMaxIdleMarkWorkers sets the maximum number of idle mark workers allowed.  This method is optimistic in that it does not wait for the number of idle mark workers to reduce to max before returning; it assumes the workers will deschedule themselves.

functions.name: setMemoryLimit
functions.desc: setMemoryLimit updates memoryLimit. commit must be called after Returns the old value of memoryLimit.  The world must be stopped, or mheap_.lock must be held.

functions.name: startCycle
functions.desc: startCycle resets the GC controller's state and computes estimates for a new GC cycle. The caller must hold worldsema and the world must be stopped.

functions.name: trigger
functions.desc: trigger returns the current point at which a GC should trigger along with the heap goal.  The returned value may be compared against heapLive to determine whether the GC should trigger. Thus, the GC trigger condition should be (but may not be, in the case of small movements for efficiency) checked whenever the heap goal may change.

functions.name: InUseBytes
functions.desc: InUseBytes returns the number of bytes in use (AllocBytes - FreeBytes).

functions.name: InUseObjects
functions.desc: InUseObjects returns the number of objects in use (AllocObjects - FreeObjects).

functions.name: Stack
functions.desc: Stack returns the stack trace associated with the record, a prefix of r.Stack0.

functions.name: next
functions.desc: next provides a new sample to the controller.  input is the sample, setpoint is the desired point, and period is how much time (in whatever unit makes the most sense) has passed since the last sample.  Returns a new value for the variable it's controlling, and whether the operation completed successfully. One reason this might fail is if error has been growing in an unbounded manner, to the point of overflow.  In the specific case of an error overflow occurs, the errOverflow field will be set and the rest of the controller's internal state will be fully reset.

functions.name: reset
functions.desc: reset resets the controller state, except for controller error flags.

functions.name: PallocData
functions.desc: Returns nil if the PallocData's L2 is missing.

functions.name: Pin
functions.desc: Pin pins a Go object, preventing it from being moved or freed by the garbage collector until the [Pinner.Unpin] method has been called.  A pointer to a pinned object can be directly stored in C memory or can be contained in Go memory passed to C functions. If the pinned object itself contains pointers to Go objects, these objects must be pinned separately if they are going to be accessed from C code.  The argument must be a pointer of any type or an [unsafe.Pointer]. It's safe to call Pin on non-Go pointers, in which case Pin will do nothing.

functions.name: Unpin
functions.desc: Unpin unpins all pinned objects of the [Pinner].

functions.name: BlockUntilParked
functions.desc: BlockUntilParked blocks until the scavenger parks, or until timeout is exceeded. Returns true if the scavenger parked.  Note that in testing, parked means something slightly different. In anger, the scavenger parks to sleep, too, but in testing, it only parks when it actually has no work to do.

functions.name: Released
functions.desc: Released returns how many bytes the scavenger released.

functions.name: Stop
functions.desc: Stop cleans up the scavenger's resources. The scavenger must be parked for this to work.

functions.name: Wake
functions.desc: Wake wakes up a parked scavenger to keep running.

functions.name: Dequeue
functions.desc: Dequeue simulates dequeuing a waiter for a semaphore (or lock) at addr.  Returns true if there actually was a waiter to be dequeued.

functions.name: Enqueue
functions.desc: Enqueue simulates enqueuing a waiter for a semaphore (or lock) at addr.

functions.name: Stack
functions.desc: Stack returns the stack trace associated with the record, a prefix of r.Stack0.

functions.name: Count
functions.desc: Count returns the counts for the given bucket, subBucket indices. Returns true if the bucket was valid, otherwise returns the counts for the overflow bucket if bucket > 0 or the underflow bucket if bucket < 0, and false.

functions.name: put
functions.desc: put inserts the data into the table.  It's always safe for callers to noescape data because put copies its bytes.  Returns a unique ID for the data and whether this is the first time the data has been added to the map.

functions.name: reset
functions.desc: reset drops all allocated memory from the table and resets it.  The caller must ensure that there are no put operations executing concurrently with this function.

functions.name: stealID
functions.desc: stealID steals an ID from the table, ensuring that it will not appear in the table anymore.

functions.name: isInlined
functions.desc: isInlined reports whether f should be re-interpreted as a *funcinl.

functions.name: nextDefer
functions.desc: nextDefer returns the next deferred function to invoke, if any.  Note: The "ok bool" result is necessary to correctly handle when the deferred function itself was nil (e.g., "defer (func())(nil)").

functions.name: nextFrame
functions.desc: nextFrame finds the next frame that contains deferred calls, if any.

functions.name: start
functions.desc: start initializes a panic to start unwinding the stack.  If p.goexit is true, then start may return multiple times.

functions.name: assignReg
functions.desc: assignReg attempts to assign a single register for an argument with the given size, at the given offset into the value in the C ABI space.  Returns whether the assignment was successful.

functions.name: tryRegAssignArg
functions.desc: tryRegAssignArg tries to register-assign a value of type t. If this type is nested in an aggregate type, then offset is the offset of this type within its parent type. Assumes t.size <= goarch.PtrSize and t.size != 0.  Returns whether the assignment succeeded.

functions.name: begin
functions.desc: begin registers a new sweeper. Returns a sweepLocker for acquiring spans for sweeping. Any outstanding sweeper blocks sweep termination.  If the sweepLocker is invalid, the caller can be sure that all outstanding sweep work has been drained, so there is nothing left to sweep. Note that there may be sweepers currently running, so this does not indicate that all sweeping has completed.  Even if the sweepLocker is invalid, its sweepGen is always valid.

functions.name: end
functions.desc: end deregisters a sweeper. Must be called once for each time begin is called if the sweepLocker is valid.

functions.name: isDone
functions.desc: isDone returns true if all sweep work has been drained and no more outstanding sweepers exist. That is, when the sweep phase is completely done.

functions.name: markDrained
functions.desc: markDrained marks the active sweep cycle as having drained all remaining work. This is safe to be called concurrently with all other methods of activeSweep, though may race.  Returns true if this call was the one that actually performed the mark.

functions.name: reset
functions.desc: reset sets up the activeSweep for the next sweep cycle.  The world must be stopped.

functions.name: sweepers
functions.desc: sweepers returns the current number of active sweepers.

functions.name: contains
functions.desc: contains returns whether or not the range contains a given address.

functions.name: removeGreaterEqual
functions.desc: removeGreaterEqual removes all addresses in a greater than or equal to addr and returns the new range.

functions.name: size
functions.desc: size returns the size of the range represented in bytes.

functions.name: subtract
functions.desc: subtract takes the addrRange toPrune and cuts out any overlap with from, then returns the new range. subtract assumes that a and b either don't overlap at all, only overlap on one side, or are equal. If b is strictly contained in a, thus forcing a split, it will throw.

functions.name: takeFromBack
functions.desc: takeFromBack takes len bytes from the end of the address range, aligning the limit to align after subtracting len. On success, returns the aligned start of the region taken and true.

functions.name: takeFromFront
functions.desc: takeFromFront takes len bytes from the front of the address range, aligning the base to align first. On success, returns the aligned start of the region taken and true.

functions.name: add
functions.desc: add inserts a new address range to a.  r must not overlap with any address range in a and r.size() must be > 0.

functions.name: cloneInto
functions.desc: cloneInto makes a deep clone of a's state into b, re-using b's ranges if able.

functions.name: contains
functions.desc: contains returns true if a covers the address addr.

functions.name: findAddrGreaterEqual
functions.desc: findAddrGreaterEqual returns the smallest address represented by a that is >= addr. Thus, if the address is represented by a, then it returns addr. The second return value indicates whether such an address exists for addr in a. That is, if addr is larger than any address known to a, the second return value will be false.

functions.name: findSucc
functions.desc: findSucc returns the first index in a such that addr is less than the base of the addrRange at that index.

functions.name: removeGreaterEqual
functions.desc: removeGreaterEqual removes the ranges of a which are above addr, and additionally splits any range containing addr.

functions.name: removeLast
functions.desc: removeLast removes and returns the highest-addressed contiguous range of a, or the last nBytes of that range, whichever is smaller. If a is empty, it returns an empty range.

functions.name: l1
functions.desc: l1 returns the "l1" portion of an arenaIdx.  Marked nosplit because it's called by spanOf and other nosplit functions.

functions.name: l2
functions.desc: l2 returns the "l2" portion of an arenaIdx.  Marked nosplit because it's called by spanOf and other nosplit funcs. functions.

functions.name: cas
functions.desc: cas atomically compares-and-swaps a headTailIndex value.

functions.name: decHead
functions.desc: decHead atomically decrements the head of a headTailIndex.

functions.name: incHead
functions.desc: incHead atomically increments the head of a headTailIndex.

functions.name: incTail
functions.desc: incTail atomically increments the tail of a headTailIndex.

functions.name: load
functions.desc: load atomically reads a headTailIndex value.

functions.name: reset
functions.desc: reset clears the headTailIndex to (0, 0).

functions.name: Load
functions.desc: Load returns the *mspan.

functions.name: StoreNoWB
functions.desc: Store stores an *mspan.

functions.name: Clear
functions.desc: Clear attempts to store minOffAddr in atomicOffAddr. It may fail if a marked value is placed in the box in the meanwhile.

functions.name: Load
functions.desc: Load returns the address in the box as a virtual address. It also returns if the value was marked or not.

functions.name: StoreMarked
functions.desc: StoreMarked stores addr but first converted to the offset address space and then negated.

functions.name: StoreMin
functions.desc: StoreMin stores addr if it's less than the current value in the offset address space if the current value is not marked.

functions.name: StoreUnmark
functions.desc: StoreUnmark attempts to unmark the value in atomicOffAddr and replace it with newAddr. markedAddr must be a marked address returned by Load. This function will not store newAddr if the box no longer contains markedAddr.

functions.name: load
functions.desc: load loads and unpacks a scavChunkData.

functions.name: store
functions.desc: store packs and writes a new scavChunkData. store must be serialized with other calls to store.

functions.name: Load
functions.desc: Loads the spanSetSpinePointer and returns it.  It has the same semantics as atomic.UnsafePointer.

functions.name: StoreNoWB
functions.desc: Stores the spanSetSpinePointer.  It has the same semantics as [atomic.UnsafePointer].

functions.name: write
functions.desc: Write to b cnt bits starting at bit 0 of data. Requires cnt>0.

functions.name: ptrbit
functions.desc: ptrbit returns the i'th bit in bv. ptrbit is less efficient than iterating directly over bitvector bits, and should only be used in non-performance-critical code. See adjustpointers for an example of a high-efficiency walk of a bitvector.

functions.name: bp
functions.desc: bp returns the blockRecord associated with the blockProfile bucket b.

functions.name: mp
functions.desc: mp returns the memRecord associated with the memProfile bucket b.

functions.name: stk
functions.desc: stk returns the slice in b holding the stack. The caller can assume that the backing array is immutable.

functions.name: l1
functions.desc: l1 returns the index into the first level of (*pageAlloc).chunks.

functions.name: l2
functions.desc: l2 returns the index into the second level of (*pageAlloc).chunks.

functions.name: empty
functions.desc: empty returns true if the cleanup block is empty.

functions.name: enqueue
functions.desc: enqueue pushes a single cleanup function into the block.  Returns if this enqueue call filled the block. This is odd, but we want to flush full blocks eagerly to get cleanups running as soon as possible.  Must only be called if the GC is in the sweep phase (gcphase == _GCoff), because it does not synchronize with the garbage collector.

functions.name: full
functions.desc: full returns true if the cleanup block is full.

functions.name: take
functions.desc: take moves as many cleanups as possible from b into a.

functions.name: addWork
functions.desc: addWork indicates that n units of parallelizable work have been added to the queue.

functions.name: blockUntilEmpty
functions.desc: blockUntilEmpty blocks until either the cleanup queue is emptied and the cleanups have been executed, or the timeout is reached. Returns true if the cleanup queue was emptied. This is used by the sync and unique tests.

functions.name: dequeue
functions.desc: dequeue pops a block of cleanups from the queue. Blocks until one is available and never returns nil.

functions.name: enqueue
functions.desc: enqueue queues a single cleanup for execution.  Called by the sweeper, and only the sweeper.

functions.name: flush
functions.desc: flush pushes all active cleanup blocks to the full list and wakes up cleanup goroutines to handle them.  Must only be called at a point when we can guarantee that no more cleanups are being queued, such as after the final sweeper for the cycle is done but before the next mark phase.

functions.name: needsWake
functions.desc: needsWake returns true if cleanup goroutines may need to be awoken or created to handle cleanup load.

functions.name: tryTakeWork
functions.desc: tryTakeWork is an attempt to dequeue some work by a cleanup goroutine. This might fail if there's no work to do.

functions.name: wake
functions.desc: wake wakes up one or more goroutines to process the cleanup queue. If there aren't enough sleeping goroutines to handle the demand, wake will arrange for new goroutines to be created.

functions.name: acquire
functions.desc: acquire returns a heapStatsDelta to be updated. In effect, it acquires the shard for writing. release must be called as soon as the relevant deltas are updated.  The returned heapStatsDelta must be updated atomically.  The caller's P must not change between acquire and release. This also means that the caller should not acquire a P or release its P in between. A P also must not acquire a given consistentHeapStats if it hasn't yet released it.  nosplit because a stack growth in this function could lead to a stack allocation that could reenter the function.

functions.name: read
functions.desc: read takes a globally consistent snapshot of m and puts the aggregated value in out. Even though out is a heapStatsDelta, the resulting values should be complete and valid statistic values.  Not safe to call concurrently. The world must be stopped or metricsSema must be held.

functions.name: release
functions.desc: release indicates that the writer is done modifying the delta. The value returned by the corresponding acquire must no longer be accessed or modified after release is called.  The caller's P must not change between acquire and release. This also means that the caller should not acquire a P or release its P in between.  nosplit because a stack growth in this function could lead to a stack allocation that causes another acquire before this operation has completed.

functions.name: unsafeClear
functions.desc: unsafeClear clears the shard.  Unsafe because the world must be stopped and values should be donated elsewhere before clearing.

functions.name: unsafeRead
functions.desc: unsafeRead aggregates the delta for this shard into out.  Unsafe because it does so without any synchronization. The world must be stopped.

functions.name: lr
functions.desc: 386 does not have link register, so this returns 0.

functions.name: set_fp
functions.desc: 386 does not have frame pointer register.

functions.name: add
functions.desc: add adds the stack trace to the profile. It is called from signal handlers and other limited environments and cannot allocate memory or acquire locks that might be held at the time of the signal, nor can it use substantial amounts of stack.

functions.name: addExtra
functions.desc: addExtra adds the "extra" profiling events, queued by addNonGo, to the profile log. addExtra is called either from a signal handler on a Go thread or from an ordinary goroutine; either way it can use stack and has a g. The world may be stopped, though.

functions.name: addNonGo
functions.desc: addNonGo adds the non-Go stack trace to the profile. It is called from a non-Go thread, so we cannot use much stack at all, nor do anything that needs a g or an m. In particular, we can't call cpuprof.log.write. Instead, we copy the stack into cpuprof.extra, which will be drained the next time a Go thread gets the signal handling event.

functions.name: accumulate
functions.desc: accumulate takes a cpuStats and adds in the current state of all GC CPU counters.  gcMarkPhase indicates that we're in the mark phase and that certain counter values should be used.

functions.name: accumulateGCPauseTime
functions.desc: accumulateGCPauseTime add dt*stwProcs to the GC CPU pause time stats. dt should be the actual time spent paused, for orthogonality. maxProcs should be GOMAXPROCS, not work.stwprocs, since this number must be comparable to a total time computed from GOMAXPROCS.

functions.name: accumulate
functions.desc: accumulate takes a cpuStats and adds in the current state of all GC CPU counters.  gcMarkPhase indicates that we're in the mark phase and that certain counter values should be used.

functions.name: accumulateGCPauseTime
functions.desc: accumulateGCPauseTime add dt*stwProcs to the GC CPU pause time stats. dt should be the actual time spent paused, for orthogonality. maxProcs should be GOMAXPROCS, not work.stwprocs, since this number must be comparable to a total time computed from GOMAXPROCS.

functions.name: compute
functions.desc: compute populates the cpuStatsAggregate with values from the runtime.

functions.name: debugCallPanicOut
functions.desc: case 2

functions.name: debugCallReturn
functions.desc: case 1

functions.name: debugCallRun
functions.desc: case 0

functions.name: debugCallUnsafe
functions.desc: case 8

functions.name: restoreSigContext
functions.desc: case 16

functions.name: Addr
functions.desc: Addr returns the memory address where a fault occurred. The address provided is best-effort. The veracity of the result may depend on the platform. Errors providing this method will only be returned as a result of using [runtime/debug.SetPanicOnFault].

functions.name: init
functions.desc: Initialize f to allocate objects of the given size, using the allocator to obtain chunks of memory.

functions.name: entry
functions.desc: entry returns the entry PC for f.  entry should be an internal detail, but widely used packages access it using linkname. Notable members of the hall of shame include:   - github.com/phuslu/log  Do not remove or change the type signature. See go.dev/issue/67401.

functions.name: isInlined
functions.desc: isInlined reports whether f should be re-interpreted as a *funcinl.

functions.name: empty
functions.desc: empty reports whether l is empty.

functions.name: pop
functions.desc: pop removes and returns the head of l. If l is empty, it returns nil.

functions.name: push
functions.desc: push adds gp to the head of l.

functions.name: pushAll
functions.desc: pushAll prepends all Gs in q to l. After this q must not be used.

functions.name: empty
functions.desc: empty reports whether q is empty.

functions.name: pop
functions.desc: pop removes and returns the head of queue q. It returns nil if q is empty.

functions.name: popList
functions.desc: popList takes all Gs in q and returns them as a gList.

functions.name: push
functions.desc: push adds gp to the head of q.

functions.name: pushBack
functions.desc: pushBack adds gp to the tail of q.

functions.name: pushBackAll
functions.desc: pushBackAll adds all Gs in q2 to the tail of q. After this q2 must not be used.

functions.name: acquireStatus
functions.desc: acquireStatus acquires the right to emit a Status event for the scheduling resource.  nosplit because it's part of writing an event for an M, which must not have any stack growth.

functions.name: nextSeq
functions.desc: nextSeq returns the next sequence number for the resource.

functions.name: readyNextGen
functions.desc: readyNextGen readies r for the generation following gen.

functions.name: reset
functions.desc: reset resets the gTraceState for a new goroutine.

functions.name: setStatusTraced
functions.desc: setStatusTraced indicates that the resource's status was already traced, for example when a goroutine is created.

functions.name: statusWasTraced
functions.desc: statusWasTraced returns true if the sched resource's status was already acquired for tracing.

functions.name: bitp
functions.desc: bitp returns a pointer to the byte containing bit n and a mask for selecting that bit from *bytep.

functions.name: bytep
functions.desc: bytep returns a pointer to the n'th byte of b.

functions.name: tryAlloc
functions.desc: tryAlloc allocates from b or returns nil if b does not have enough room. This is safe to call concurrently.

functions.name: accumulate
functions.desc: accumulate adds time to the bucket and signals whether the limiter is enabled.  This is an internal function that deals just with the bucket. Prefer update. l.lock must be held.

functions.name: addAssistTime
functions.desc: addAssistTime notifies the limiter of additional assist time. It will be included in the next update.

functions.name: addIdleTime
functions.desc: addIdleTime notifies the limiter of additional time a P spent on the idle list. It will be subtracted from the total CPU time in the next update.

functions.name: finishGCTransition
functions.desc: finishGCTransition notifies the limiter that the GC transition is complete and releases ownership of it. It also accumulates STW time in the bucket. now must be the timestamp from the end of the STW pause.

functions.name: limiting
functions.desc: limiting returns true if the CPU limiter is currently enabled, meaning the Go GC should take action to limit CPU utilization.  It is safe to call concurrently with other operations.

functions.name: needUpdate
functions.desc: needUpdate returns true if the limiter's maximum update period has been exceeded, and so would benefit from an update.

functions.name: resetCapacity
functions.desc: resetCapacity updates the capacity based on GOMAXPROCS. Must not be called while the GC is enabled.  It is safe to call concurrently with other operations.

functions.name: startGCTransition
functions.desc: startGCTransition notifies the limiter of a GC transition.  This call takes ownership of the limiter and disables all other means of updating the limiter. Release ownership by calling finishGCTransition.  It is safe to call concurrently with other operations.

functions.name: tryLock
functions.desc: tryLock attempts to lock l. Returns true on success.

functions.name: unlock
functions.desc: unlock releases the lock on l. Must be called if tryLock returns true.

functions.name: update
functions.desc: update updates the bucket given runtime-specific information. now is the current monotonic time in nanoseconds.  This is safe to call concurrently with other operations, except *GCTransition.

functions.name: updateLocked
functions.desc: updateLocked is the implementation of update. l.lock must be held.

functions.name: addIdleMarkWorker
functions.desc: addIdleMarkWorker attempts to add a new idle mark worker.  If this returns true, the caller must become an idle mark worker unless there's no background mark worker goroutines in the pool. This case is harmless because there are already background mark workers running. If this returns false, the caller must NOT become an idle mark worker.  nosplit because it may be called without a P.

functions.name: commit
functions.desc: commit recomputes all pacing parameters needed to derive the trigger and the heap goal. Namely, the gcPercent-based heap goal, and the amount of runway we want to give the GC this cycle.  This can be called any time. If GC is the in the middle of a concurrent phase, it will adjust the pacing of that phase.  isSweepDone should be the result of calling isSweepDone(), unless we're testing or we know we're executing during a GC cycle.  This depends on gcPercent, gcController.heapMarked, and gcController.heapLive. These must be up to date.  Callers must call gcControllerState.revise after calling this function if the GC is enabled.  mheap_.lock must be held or the world must be stopped.

functions.name: endCycle
functions.desc: endCycle computes the consMark estimate for the next cycle. userForced indicates whether the current GC cycle was forced by the application.

functions.name: enlistWorker
functions.desc: enlistWorker encourages another dedicated mark worker to start on another P if there are spare worker slots. It is used by putfull when more work is made available.  If goexperiment.GreenTeaGC, the caller must not hold a G's scan bit, otherwise this could cause a deadlock. This is already enforced by the static lock ranking.

functions.name: findRunnableGCWorker
functions.desc: findRunnableGCWorker returns a background mark worker for pp if it should be run. This must only be called when gcBlackenEnabled != 0.

functions.name: heapGoal
functions.desc: heapGoal returns the current heap goal.

functions.name: heapGoalInternal
functions.desc: heapGoalInternal is the implementation of heapGoal which returns additional information that is necessary for computing the trigger.  The returned minTrigger is always <= goal.

functions.name: markWorkerStop
functions.desc: markWorkerStop must be called whenever a mark worker stops executing.  It updates mark work accounting in the controller by a duration of work in nanoseconds and other bookkeeping.  Safe to execute at any time.

functions.name: memoryLimitHeapGoal
functions.desc: memoryLimitHeapGoal returns a heap goal derived from memoryLimit.

functions.name: needIdleMarkWorker
functions.desc: needIdleMarkWorker is a hint as to whether another idle mark worker is needed.  The caller must still call addIdleMarkWorker to become one. This is mainly useful for a quick check before an expensive operation.  nosplit because it may be called without a P.

functions.name: removeIdleMarkWorker
functions.desc: removeIdleMarkWorker must be called when a new idle mark worker stops executing.

functions.name: resetLive
functions.desc: resetLive sets up the controller state for the next mark phase after the end of the previous one. Must be called after endCycle and before commit, before the world is started.  The world must be stopped.

functions.name: revise
