types.name: Tag
types.desc: Tag represents an ASN.1 identifier octet, consisting of a tag number (indicating a type) and class (such as context-specific or constructed).  Methods in the cryptobyte package only support the low-tag-number form, i.e. a single identifier octet with bits 7-8 encoding the class and bits 1-6 encoding the tag number.

name: vendor/golang.org/x/net/dns/dnsmessage
desc: Package dnsmessage provides a mostly RFC 1035 compliant implementation of DNS message packing and unpacking.  The package also supports messages with Extension Mechanisms for DNS (EDNS(0)) as defined in RFC 6891.  This implementation is designed to minimize heap allocations and avoid unnecessary packing and unpacking as much as possible.

functions.name: EnableCompression
functions.desc: EnableCompression enables compression in the Builder.  Leaving compression disabled avoids compression related allocations, but can result in larger message sizes. Be careful with this mode as it can cause messages to exceed the UDP size limit.  According to RFC 1035, section 4.1.4, the use of compression is optional, but all implementations must accept both compressed and uncompressed DNS messages.  Compression should be enabled before any sections are added for best results.

types.name: AAAAResource
types.desc: An AAAAResource is an AAAA Resource record.

types.name: AResource
types.desc: An AResource is an A Resource record.

types.name: Builder
types.desc: A Builder allows incrementally packing a DNS message.  Example usage:  	buf := make([]byte, 2, 514) 	b := NewBuilder(buf, Header{...}) 	b.EnableCompression() 	// Optionally start a section and add things to that section. 	// Repeat adding sections as necessary. 	buf, err := b.Finish() 	// If err is nil, buf[2:] will contain the built bytes.

types.name: CNAMEResource
types.desc: A CNAMEResource is a CNAME Resource record.

types.name: Class
types.desc: A Class is a type of network.

types.name: Header
types.desc: Header is a representation of a DNS message header.

types.name: MXResource
types.desc: An MXResource is an MX Resource record.

types.name: Message
types.desc: Message is a representation of a DNS message.

types.name: NSResource
types.desc: An NSResource is an NS Resource record.

types.name: Name
types.desc: A Name is a non-encoded and non-escaped domain name. It is used instead of strings to avoid allocations.

types.name: OPTResource
types.desc: An OPTResource is an OPT pseudo Resource record.  The pseudo resource record is part of the extension mechanisms for DNS as defined in RFC 6891.

types.name: OpCode
types.desc: An OpCode is a DNS operation code.

types.name: Option
types.desc: An Option represents a DNS message option within OPTResource.  The message option is part of the extension mechanisms for DNS as defined in RFC 6891.

types.name: PTRResource
types.desc: A PTRResource is a PTR Resource record.

types.name: Parser
types.desc: A Parser allows incrementally parsing a DNS message.  When parsing is started, the Header is parsed. Next, each Question can be either parsed or skipped. Alternatively, all Questions can be skipped at once. When all Questions have been parsed, attempting to parse Questions will return the [ErrSectionDone] error. After all Questions have been either parsed or skipped, all Answers, Authorities and Additionals can be either parsed or skipped in the same way, and each type of Resource must be fully parsed or skipped before proceeding to the next type of Resource.  Parser is safe to copy to preserve the parsing state.  Note that there is no requirement to fully skip or parse the message.

types.name: Question
types.desc: A Question is a DNS query.

types.name: RCode
types.desc: An RCode is a DNS response status code.

types.name: Resource
types.desc: A Resource is a DNS resource record.

types.name: ResourceBody
types.desc: A ResourceBody is a DNS resource record minus the header.

types.name: ResourceHeader
types.desc: A ResourceHeader is the header of a DNS resource record. There are many types of DNS resource records, but they all share the same header.

types.name: SOAResource
types.desc: An SOAResource is an SOA Resource record.

types.name: SRVResource
types.desc: An SRVResource is an SRV Resource record.

types.name: TXTResource
types.desc: A TXTResource is a TXT Resource record.

types.name: Type
types.desc: A Type is a type of DNS request and response.

types.name: UnknownResource
types.desc: An UnknownResource is a catch-all container for unknown record types.

types.name: header
types.desc: header is the wire format for a DNS message header.

name: vendor/golang.org/x/net/http/httpguts
desc: Package httpguts provides functions implementing various details of the HTTP specification.  This package is shared by the standard library (which vendors it) and x/net/http2. It comes with no API stability promise.

functions.name: HeaderValuesContainsToken
functions.desc: HeaderValuesContainsToken reports whether any string in values contains the provided token, ASCII case-insensitively.

functions.name: PunycodeHostPort
functions.desc: PunycodeHostPort returns the IDNA Punycode version of the provided "host" or "host:port" string.

functions.name: ValidHeaderFieldName
functions.desc: ValidHeaderFieldName reports whether v is a valid HTTP/1.x header name. HTTP/2 imposes the additional restriction that uppercase ASCII letters are not allowed.  RFC 7230 says:  	header-field   = field-name ":" OWS field-value OWS 	field-name     = token 	token          = 1*tchar 	tchar = "!" / "#" / "$" / "%" / "&" / "'" / "*" / "+" / "-" / "." / 	        "^" / "_" / "`" / "|" / "~" / DIGIT / ALPHA

functions.name: ValidHeaderFieldValue
functions.desc: ValidHeaderFieldValue reports whether v is a valid "field-value" according to http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec4.html#sec4.2 :  	message-header = field-name ":" [ field-value ] 	field-value    = *( field-content | LWS ) 	field-content  = <the OCTETs making up the field-value 	                 and consisting of either *TEXT or combinations 	                 of token, separators, and quoted-string>  http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec2.html#sec2.2 :  	TEXT           = <any OCTET except CTLs, 	                  but including LWS> 	LWS            = [CRLF] 1*( SP | HT ) 	CTL            = <any US-ASCII control character 	                 (octets 0 - 31) and DEL (127)>  RFC 7230 says:  	field-value    = *( field-content / obs-fold ) 	obj-fold       =  N/A to http2, and deprecated 	field-content  = field-vchar [ 1*( SP / HTAB ) field-vchar ] 	field-vchar    = VCHAR / obs-text 	obs-text       = %x80-FF 	VCHAR          = "any visible [USASCII] character"  http2 further says: "Similarly, HTTP/2 allows header field values that are not valid. While most of the values that can be encoded will not alter header field parsing, carriage return (CR, ASCII 0xd), line feed (LF, ASCII 0xa), and the zero character (NUL, ASCII 0x0) might be exploited by an attacker if they are translated verbatim. Any request or response that contains a character not permitted in a header field value MUST be treated as malformed (Section 8.1.2.6). Valid characters are defined by the field-content ABNF rule in Section 3.2 of [RFC7230]."  This function does not (yet?) properly handle the rejection of strings that begin or end with SP or HTAB.

functions.name: ValidHostHeader
functions.desc: ValidHostHeader reports whether h is a valid host header.

functions.name: ValidTrailerHeader
functions.desc: ValidTrailerHeader reports whether name is a valid header field name to appear in trailers. See RFC 7230, Section 4.1.2

functions.name: headerValueContainsToken
functions.desc: headerValueContainsToken reports whether v (assumed to be a 0#element, in the ABNF extension described in RFC 7230 section 7) contains token amongst its comma-separated tokens, ASCII case-insensitively.

functions.name: isCTL
functions.desc: isCTL reports whether b is a control byte, according to http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec2.html#sec2.2  	CTL            = <any US-ASCII control character 	                 (octets 0 - 31) and DEL (127)>

functions.name: isLWS
functions.desc: isLWS reports whether b is linear white space, according to http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec2.html#sec2.2  	LWS            = [CRLF] 1*( SP | HT )

functions.name: isOWS
functions.desc: isOWS reports whether b is an optional whitespace byte, as defined by RFC 7230 section 3.2.3.

functions.name: lowerASCII
functions.desc: lowerASCII returns the ASCII lowercase version of b.

functions.name: tokenEqual
functions.desc: tokenEqual reports whether t1 and t2 are equal, ASCII case-insensitively.

functions.name: trimOWS
functions.desc: trimOWS returns x with all optional whitespace removes from the beginning and end.

name: vendor/golang.org/x/net/http/httpproxy
desc: Package httpproxy provides support for HTTP proxy determination based on environment variables, as provided by net/http's ProxyFromEnvironment function.  The API is not subject to the Go 1 compatibility promise and may change at any time.

functions.name: canonicalAddr
functions.desc: canonicalAddr returns url.Host but always with a ":port" suffix

functions.name: hasPort
functions.desc: Given a string of the form "host", "host:port", or "[ipv6::address]:port", return true if the string includes a port.

functions.name: ProxyFunc
functions.desc: ProxyFunc returns a function that determines the proxy URL to use for a given request URL. Changing the contents of cfg will not affect proxy functions created earlier.  A nil URL and nil error are returned if no proxy is defined in the environment, or a proxy should not be used for the given request, as defined by NO_PROXY.  As a special case, if req.URL.Host is "localhost" or a loopback address (with or without a port number), then a nil URL and nil error will be returned.

functions.name: useProxy
functions.desc: useProxy reports whether requests to addr should use a proxy, according to the NO_PROXY or no_proxy environment variable. addr is always a canonicalAddr with a host and port.

types.name: Config
types.desc: Config holds configuration for HTTP proxy settings. See FromEnvironment for details.

types.name: allMatch
types.desc: allMatch matches on all possible inputs

types.name: config
types.desc: config holds the parsed configuration for HTTP proxy settings.

types.name: matcher
types.desc: matcher represents the matching rule for a given value in the NO_PROXY list

name: vendor/golang.org/x/net/http2/hpack
desc: Package hpack implements HPACK, a compression format for efficiently representing HTTP header fields in the context of HTTP/2.  See http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-httpbis-header-compression-09

functions.name: AppendHuffmanString
functions.desc: AppendHuffmanString appends s, as encoded in Huffman codes, to dst and returns the extended buffer.

functions.name: HuffmanDecode
functions.desc: HuffmanDecode decodes the string in v and writes the expanded result to w, returning the number of bytes written to w and the Write call's return value. At most one Write call is made.

functions.name: HuffmanDecodeToString
functions.desc: HuffmanDecodeToString decodes the string in v.

functions.name: HuffmanEncodeLength
functions.desc: HuffmanEncodeLength returns the number of bytes required to encode s in Huffman codes. The result is round up to byte boundary.

functions.name: appendHpackString
functions.desc: appendHpackString appends s, as encoded in "String Literal" representation, to dst and returns the extended buffer.  s will be encoded in Huffman codes only when it produces strictly shorter byte string.

functions.name: appendIndexed
functions.desc: appendIndexed appends index i, as encoded in "Indexed Header Field" representation, to dst and returns the extended buffer.

functions.name: appendIndexedName
functions.desc: appendIndexedName appends f and index i referring indexed name entry, as encoded in one of "Literal Header field - Indexed Name" representation variants, to dst and returns the extended buffer.  If f.Sensitive is true, "Never Indexed" representation is used. If f.Sensitive is false and indexing is true, "Incremental Indexing" representation is used.

functions.name: appendNewName
functions.desc: appendNewName appends f, as encoded in one of "Literal Header field - New Name" representation variants, to dst and returns the extended buffer.  If f.Sensitive is true, "Never Indexed" representation is used. If f.Sensitive is false and indexing is true, "Incremental Indexing" representation is used.

functions.name: appendTableSize
functions.desc: appendTableSize appends v, as encoded in "Header Table Size Update" representation, to dst and returns the extended buffer.

functions.name: appendVarInt
functions.desc: appendVarInt appends i, as encoded in variable integer form using n bit prefix, to dst and returns the extended buffer.  See https://httpwg.org/specs/rfc7541.html#integer.representation

functions.name: encodeTypeByte
functions.desc: encodeTypeByte returns type byte. If sensitive is true, type byte for "Never Indexed" representation is returned. If sensitive is false and indexing is true, type byte for "Incremental Indexing" representation is returned. Otherwise, type byte for "Without Indexing" is returned.

functions.name: huffmanDecode
functions.desc: huffmanDecode decodes v to buf. If maxLen is greater than 0, attempts to write more to buf than maxLen bytes will return ErrStringLength.

functions.name: readVarInt
functions.desc: readVarInt reads an unsigned variable length integer off the beginning of p. n is the parameter as described in https://httpwg.org/specs/rfc7541.html#rfc.section.5.1.  n must always be between 1 and 8.  The returned remain buffer is either a smaller suffix of p, or err != nil. The error is errNeedMore if p doesn't contain a complete integer.

functions.name: Close
functions.desc: Close declares that the decoding is complete and resets the Decoder to be reused again for a new header block. If there is any remaining data in the decoder's buffer, Close returns an error.

functions.name: DecodeFull
functions.desc: DecodeFull decodes an entire block.  TODO: remove this method and make it incremental later? This is easier for debugging now.

functions.name: EmitEnabled
functions.desc: EmitEnabled reports whether calls to the emitFunc provided to NewDecoder are currently enabled. The default is true.

functions.name: SetAllowedMaxDynamicTableSize
functions.desc: SetAllowedMaxDynamicTableSize sets the upper bound that the encoded stream (via dynamic table size updates) may set the maximum size to.

functions.name: SetEmitEnabled
functions.desc: SetEmitEnabled controls whether the emitFunc provided to NewDecoder should be called. The default is true.  This facility exists to let servers enforce MAX_HEADER_LIST_SIZE while still decoding and keeping in-sync with decoder state, but without doing unnecessary decompression or generating unnecessary garbage for header fields past the limit.

functions.name: SetEmitFunc
functions.desc: SetEmitFunc changes the callback used when new header fields are decoded. It must be non-nil. It does not affect EmitEnabled.

functions.name: SetMaxStringLength
functions.desc: SetMaxStringLength sets the maximum size of a HeaderField name or value string. If a string exceeds this length (even after any decompression), Write will return ErrStringLength. A value of 0 means unlimited and is the default from NewDecoder.

functions.name: parseDynamicTableSizeUpdate
functions.desc: (same invariants and behavior as parseHeaderFieldRepr)

functions.name: parseFieldIndexed
functions.desc: (same invariants and behavior as parseHeaderFieldRepr)

functions.name: parseFieldLiteral
functions.desc: (same invariants and behavior as parseHeaderFieldRepr)

functions.name: parseHeaderFieldRepr
functions.desc: returns errNeedMore if there isn't enough data available. any other error is fatal. consumes d.buf iff it returns nil. precondition: must be called with len(d.buf) > 0

functions.name: readString
functions.desc: readString reads an hpack string from p.  It returns a reference to the encoded string data to permit deferring decode costs until after the caller verifies all data is present.

functions.name: MaxDynamicTableSize
functions.desc: MaxDynamicTableSize returns the current dynamic header table size.

functions.name: SetMaxDynamicTableSize
functions.desc: SetMaxDynamicTableSize changes the dynamic header table size to v. The actual size is bounded by the value passed to SetMaxDynamicTableSizeLimit.

functions.name: SetMaxDynamicTableSizeLimit
functions.desc: SetMaxDynamicTableSizeLimit changes the maximum value that can be specified in SetMaxDynamicTableSize to v. By default, it is set to 4096, which is the same size of the default dynamic header table size described in HPACK specification. If the current maximum dynamic header table size is strictly greater than v, "Header Table Size Update" will be done in the next WriteField call and the maximum dynamic header table size is truncated to v.

functions.name: WriteField
functions.desc: WriteField encodes f into a single Write to e's underlying Writer. This function may also produce bytes for "Header Table Size Update" if necessary. If produced, it is done before encoding f.

functions.name: searchTable
functions.desc: searchTable searches f in both stable and dynamic header tables. The static header table is searched first. Only when there is no exact match for both name and value, the dynamic header table is then searched. If there is no match, i is 0. If both name and value match, i is the matched index and nameValueMatch becomes true. If only name matches, i points to that index and nameValueMatch becomes false.

functions.name: shouldIndex
functions.desc: shouldIndex reports whether f should be indexed.

functions.name: IsPseudo
functions.desc: IsPseudo reports whether the header field is an http2 pseudo header. That is, it reports whether it starts with a colon. It is not otherwise guaranteed to be a valid pseudo header field, though.

functions.name: Size
functions.desc: Size returns the size of an entry per RFC 7541 section 4.1.

functions.name: evict
functions.desc: If we're too big, evict old stuff.

functions.name: addEntry
functions.desc: addEntry adds a new entry.

functions.name: evictOldest
functions.desc: evictOldest evicts the n oldest entries in the table.

functions.name: idToIndex
functions.desc: idToIndex converts a unique id to an HPACK index. See Section 2.3.3.

functions.name: len
functions.desc: len reports the number of entries in the table.

functions.name: search
functions.desc: search finds f in the table. If there is no match, i is 0. If both name and value match, i is the matched index and nameValueMatch becomes true. If only name matches, i points to that index and nameValueMatch becomes false.  The returned index is a 1-based HPACK index. For dynamic tables, HPACK says that index 1 should be the newest entry, but t.ents[0] is the oldest entry, meaning t.ents is reversed for dynamic tables. Hence, when t is a dynamic table, the return value i actually refers to the entry t.ents[t.len()-i].  All tables are assumed to be a dynamic tables except for the global staticTable.  See Section 2.3.3.

types.name: Decoder
types.desc: A Decoder is the decoding context for incremental processing of header blocks.

types.name: DecodingError
types.desc: A DecodingError is something the spec defines as a decoding error.

types.name: HeaderField
types.desc: A HeaderField is a name-value pair. Both the name and value are treated as opaque sequences of octets.

types.name: InvalidIndexError
types.desc: An InvalidIndexError is returned when an encoder references a table entry before the static table or after the end of the dynamic table.

types.name: headerFieldTable
types.desc: headerFieldTable implements a list of HeaderFields. This is used to implement the static and dynamic tables.

types.name: incomparable
types.desc: incomparable is a zero-width, non-comparable type. Adding it to a struct makes that struct also non-comparable, and generally doesn't add any size (as long as it's first).

name: vendor/golang.org/x/net/idna
desc: Package idna implements IDNA2008 using the compatibility processing defined by UTS (Unicode Technical Standard) #46, which defines a standard to deal with the transition from IDNA2003.  IDNA2008 (Internationalized Domain Names for Applications), is defined in RFC 5890, RFC 5891, RFC 5892, RFC 5893 and RFC 5894. UTS #46 is defined in https://www.unicode.org/reports/tr46. See https://unicode.org/cldr/utility/idna.jsp for a visualization of the differences between these two standards.  Package idna implements IDNA2008 using the compatibility processing defined by UTS (Unicode Technical Standard) #46, which defines a standard to deal with the transition from IDNA2003.  IDNA2008 (Internationalized Domain Names for Applications), is defined in RFC 5890, RFC 5891, RFC 5892, RFC 5893 and RFC 5894. UTS #46 is defined in https://www.unicode.org/reports/tr46. See https://unicode.org/cldr/utility/idna.jsp for a visualization of the differences between these two standards.

functions.name: ToASCII
functions.desc: ToASCII is a wrapper for Punycode.ToASCII.

functions.name: ToUnicode
functions.desc: ToUnicode is a wrapper for Punycode.ToUnicode.

functions.name: adapt
functions.desc: adapt is the bias adaptation function specified in section 6.1.

functions.name: decode
functions.desc: decode decodes a string as specified in section 6.2.

functions.name: encode
functions.desc: encode encodes a string as specified in section 6.3 and prepends prefix to the result.  The "while h < length(input)" line in the specification becomes "for remaining != 0" in the Go code, because len(s) in Go is in bytes, not runes.

functions.name: madd
functions.desc: madd computes a + (b * c), detecting overflow.

functions.name: String
functions.desc: String reports a string with a description of the profile for debugging purposes. The string format may change with different versions.

functions.name: ToASCII
functions.desc: ToASCII converts a domain or domain label to its ASCII form. For example, ToASCII("bcher.example.com") is "xn--bcher-kva.example.com", and ToASCII("golang") is "golang". If an error is encountered it will return an error and a (partially) processed result.

functions.name: ToUnicode
functions.desc: ToUnicode converts a domain or domain label to its Unicode form. For example, ToUnicode("xn--bcher-kva.example.com") is "bcher.example.com", and ToUnicode("golang") is "golang". If an error is encountered it will return an error and a (partially) processed result.

functions.name: process
functions.desc: process implements the algorithm described in section 4 of UTS #46, see https://www.unicode.org/reports/tr46.

functions.name: validateLabel
functions.desc: validateLabel validates the criteria from Section 4.1. Item 1, 4, and 6 are already implicitly satisfied by the overall implementation.

functions.name: lookup
functions.desc: lookup returns the trie value for the first UTF-8 encoding in s and the width in bytes of this encoding. The size will be 0 if s does not hold enough bytes to complete the encoding. len(s) must be greater than 0.

functions.name: lookupString
functions.desc: lookupString returns the trie value for the first UTF-8 encoding in s and the width in bytes of this encoding. The size will be 0 if s does not hold enough bytes to complete the encoding. len(s) must be greater than 0.

functions.name: lookupStringUnsafe
functions.desc: lookupStringUnsafe returns the trie value for the first UTF-8 encoding in s. s must start with a full and valid UTF-8 encoded rune.

functions.name: lookupUnsafe
functions.desc: lookupUnsafe returns the trie value for the first UTF-8 encoding in s. s must start with a full and valid UTF-8 encoded rune.

functions.name: lookupValue
functions.desc: lookupValue determines the type of block n and looks up the value for b.

functions.name: appendMapping
functions.desc: appendMapping appends the mapping for the respective rune. isMapped must be true. A mapping is a categorization of a rune as defined in UTS #46.

functions.name: next
functions.desc: next sets the value to the next label. It skips the last label if it is empty.

functions.name: lookup
functions.desc: lookup determines the type of block n and looks up the value for b. For n < t.cutoff, the block is a simple lookup table. Otherwise, the block is a list of ranges with an accompanying value. Given a matching range r, the value for b is by r.value + (b - r.lo) * stride.

types.name: Option
types.desc: An Option configures a Profile at creation time.

types.name: Profile
types.desc: A Profile defines the configuration of a IDNA mapper.

types.name: category
types.desc: A category corresponds to a category defined in the IDNA mapping table.

types.name: idnaTrie
types.desc: idnaTrie. Total size: 28600 bytes (27.93 KiB). Checksum: 95575047b5d8fff.

types.name: info
types.desc: info holds information from the IDNA mapping table for a single rune. It is the value returned by a trie lookup. In most cases, all information fits in a 16-bit value. For mappings, this value may contain an index into a slice with the mapped string. Such mappings can consist of the actual mapped value or an XOR pattern to be applied to the bytes of the UTF8 encoding of the input rune. This technique is used by the cases packages and reduces the table size significantly.  The per-rune values have the following format:  	if mapped { 	  if inlinedXOR { 	    15..13 inline XOR marker 	    12..11 unused 	    10..3  inline XOR mask 	  } else { 	    15..3  index into xor or mapping table 	  } 	} else { 	    15..14 unused 	    13     mayNeedNorm 	    12..11 attributes 	    10..8  joining type 	     7..3  category type 	} 	   2  use xor pattern 	1..0  mapped category  See the definitions below for a more detailed description of the various bits.

types.name: labelIter
types.desc: A labelIter allows iterating over domain name labels.

name: vendor/golang.org/x/net/lif
desc: Package lif provides basic functions for the manipulation of logical network interfaces and interface addresses on Solaris.  The package supports Solaris 11 or above.

functions.name: Family
functions.desc: Family implements the Family method of Addr interface.

functions.name: Family
functions.desc: Family implements the Family method of Addr interface.

types.name: Addr
types.desc: An Addr represents an address associated with packet routing.

types.name: Inet4Addr
types.desc: An Inet4Addr represents an internet address for IPv4.

types.name: Inet6Addr
types.desc: An Inet6Addr represents an internet address for IPv6.

types.name: Link
types.desc: A Link represents logical data link information.  It also represents base information for logical network interface. On Solaris, each logical network interface represents network layer adjacency information and the interface has a only single network address or address pair for tunneling. It's usual that multiple logical network interfaces share the same logical data link.

name: vendor/golang.org/x/net/nettest
desc: Package nettest provides utilities for network testing.

functions.name: LocalPath
functions.desc: LocalPath returns a local path that can be used for Unix-domain protocol testing.

functions.name: LoopbackInterface
functions.desc: LoopbackInterface returns an available logical network interface for loopback test.

functions.name: MulticastSource
functions.desc: MulticastSource returns a unicast IP address on ifi when ifi is an IP multicast-capable network interface.  The provided network must be "ip", "ip4" or "ip6".

functions.name: NewLocalListener
functions.desc: NewLocalListener returns a listener which listens to a loopback IP address or local file system path.  The provided network must be "tcp", "tcp4", "tcp6", "unix" or "unixpacket".

functions.name: NewLocalPacketListener
functions.desc: NewLocalPacketListener returns a packet listener which listens to a loopback IP address or local file system path.  The provided network must be "udp", "udp4", "udp6" or "unixgram".

functions.name: RoutedInterface
functions.desc: RoutedInterface returns a network interface that can route IP traffic and satisfies flags.  The provided network must be "ip", "ip4" or "ip6".

functions.name: SupportsIPv4
functions.desc: SupportsIPv4 reports whether the platform supports IPv4 networking functionality.

functions.name: SupportsIPv6
functions.desc: SupportsIPv6 reports whether the platform supports IPv6 networking functionality.

functions.name: SupportsRawSocket
functions.desc: SupportsRawSocket reports whether the current session is available to use raw sockets.

functions.name: TestConn
functions.desc: TestConn tests that a net.Conn implementation properly satisfies the interface. The tests should not produce any false positives, but may experience false negatives. Thus, some issues may only be detected when the test is run multiple times. For maximal effectiveness, run the tests under the race detector.

functions.name: TestableAddress
functions.desc: TestableAddress reports whether address of network is testable on the current platform configuration.

functions.name: TestableNetwork
functions.desc: TestableNetwork reports whether network is testable on the current platform configuration.  See func Dial of the standard library for the supported networks.

functions.name: checkForTimeoutError
functions.desc: checkForTimeoutError checks that the error satisfies the Error interface and that Timeout returns true.

functions.name: chunkedCopy
functions.desc: chunkedCopy copies from r to w in fixed-width chunks to avoid causing a Write that exceeds the maximum packet size for packet-based connections like "unixpacket". We assume that the maximum packet size is at least 1024.

functions.name: resyncConn
functions.desc: resyncConn resynchronizes the connection into a sane state. It assumes that everything written into c is echoed back to itself. It assumes that 0xff is not currently on the wire or in the read buffer.

functions.name: testBasicIO
functions.desc: testBasicIO tests that the data sent on c1 is properly received on c2.

functions.name: testCloseTimeout
functions.desc: testCloseTimeout tests that calling Close immediately times out pending Read and Write operations.

functions.name: testConcurrentMethods
functions.desc: testConcurrentMethods tests that the methods of net.Conn can safely be called concurrently.

functions.name: testFutureTimeout
functions.desc: testFutureTimeout tests that a future deadline will eventually time out Read and Write operations.

functions.name: testPastTimeout
functions.desc: testPastTimeout tests that a deadline set in the past immediately times out Read and Write requests.

functions.name: testPingPong
functions.desc: testPingPong tests that the two endpoints can synchronously send data to each other in a typical request-response pattern.

functions.name: testPresentTimeout
functions.desc: testPresentTimeout tests that a past deadline set while there are pending Read and Write operations immediately times out those operations.

functions.name: testRacyRead
functions.desc: testRacyRead tests that it is safe to mutate the input Read buffer immediately after cancelation has occurred.

functions.name: testRacyWrite
functions.desc: testRacyWrite tests that it is safe to mutate the input Write buffer immediately after cancelation has occurred.

functions.name: testReadTimeout
functions.desc: testReadTimeout tests that Read timeouts do not affect Write.

functions.name: testRoundtrip
functions.desc: testRoundtrip writes something into c and reads it back. It assumes that everything written into c is echoed back to itself.

functions.name: testWriteTimeout
functions.desc: testWriteTimeout tests that Write timeouts do not affect Read.

types.name: MakePipe
types.desc: MakePipe creates a connection between two endpoints and returns the pair as c1 and c2, such that anything written to c1 is read by c2 and vice-versa. The stop function closes all resources, including c1, c2, and the underlying net.Listener (if there is one), and should not be nil.

name: vendor/golang.org/x/sys/cpu
desc: Package cpu implements processor feature detection for various CPU architectures.

functions.name: bitIsSet
functions.desc: bitIsSet reports whether the bit at index is set. The bit index is in big endian order, so bit index 0 is the leftmost bit.

functions.name: cpuid
functions.desc: cpuid is implemented in cpu_gc_x86.s for gc compiler and in cpu_gccgo.c for gccgo.

functions.name: darwinKernelVersionCheck
functions.desc: Ensure Darwin kernel version is at least major.minor.patch, avoiding dependencies

functions.name: darwinOSRelease
functions.desc: adapted from unix.Uname() at x/sys/unix/syscall_darwin.go L419

functions.name: darwinSupportsAVX512
functions.desc: darwinSupportsAVX512 checks Darwin kernel for AVX512 support via sysctl call (see issue 43089). It also restricts AVX512 support for Darwin to kernel version 21.3.0 (MacOS 12.2.0) or later (see issue 49233).  Background: Darwin implements a special mechanism to economize on thread state when AVX512 specific registers are not in use. This scheme minimizes state when preempting threads that haven't yet used any AVX512 instructions, but adds special requirements to check for AVX512 hardware support at runtime (e.g. via sysctl call or commpage inspection). See issue 43089 and link below for full background: https://github.com/apple-oss-distributions/xnu/blob/xnu-11215.1.10/osfmk/i386/fpu.c#L214-L240  Additionally, all versions of the Darwin kernel from 19.6.0 through 21.2.0 (corresponding to MacOS 10.15.6 - 12.1) have a bug that can cause corruption of the AVX512 mask registers (K0-K7) upon signal return. For this reason AVX512 is considered unsafe to use on Darwin for kernel versions prior to 21.3.0, where a fix has been confirmed. See issue 49233 for full background.

functions.name: darwinSysctlEnabled
functions.desc: adapted from internal/cpu/cpu_arm64_darwin.go

functions.name: haveAsmFunctions

functions.name: linuxKernelCanEmulateCPUID
functions.desc: linuxKernelCanEmulateCPUID reports whether we're running on Linux 4.11+. Ideally we'd like to ask the question about whether the current kernel contains https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/torvalds/linux.git/commit/?id=77c97b4ee21290f5f083173d957843b615abbff2 but the version number will have to do.

functions.name: parseRelease
functions.desc: parseRelease parses a dot-separated version number. It follows the semver syntax, but allows the minor and patch versions to be elided.  This is a copy of the Go runtime's parseRelease from https://golang.org/cl/209597.

functions.name: rawSyscall6
functions.desc: Implemented in runtime/syscall_aix.go.

functions.name: riscvHWProbe
functions.desc: riscvHWProbe is a simplified version of the generated wrapper function found in golang.org/x/sys/unix/zsyscall_linux_riscv64.go. We simplify it by removing the cpuCount and cpus parameters which we do not need. We always want to pass 0 for these parameters here so the kernel only reports the extensions that are present on all cores.

functions.name: setMinimalFeatures
functions.desc: setMinimalFeatures fakes the minimal ARM64 features expected by TestARM64minimalFeatures.

functions.name: syscall_syscall6
functions.desc: Implemented in the runtime package (runtime/sys_openbsd3.go)

functions.name: sysctl
functions.desc: from x/sys/unix/zsyscall_darwin_amd64.go L791-807

functions.desc: adapted from runtime/sys_darwin.go in the pattern of sysctl() above, as defined in x/sys/unix

functions.name: xgetbv
functions.desc: xgetbv with ecx = 0 is implemented in cpu_gc_x86.s for gc compiler and in cpu_gccgo.c for gccgo.

functions.name: Has

functions.name: Has

types.name: aarch64SysctlCPUID
types.desc: aarch64SysctlCPUID is struct aarch64_sysctl_cpu_id from NetBSD's <aarch64/armreg.h>

types.name: byteOrder
types.desc: byteOrder is a subset of encoding/binary.ByteOrder.

types.name: facility

types.name: facilityList
types.desc: facilityList contains the result of an STFLE call. Bits are numbered in big endian order so the leftmost bit (the MSB) is at index 0.

types.name: queryResult

types.name: riscvHWProbePairs
types.desc: riscvHWProbePairs is copied from golang.org/x/sys/unix/ztypes_linux_riscv64.go.

name: vendor/golang.org/x/text/secure/bidirule
desc: Package bidirule implements the Bidi Rule defined by RFC 5893.  This package is under development. The API may change without notice and without preserving backward compatibility.

functions.name: Direction
functions.desc: Direction reports the direction of the given label as defined by RFC 5893. The Bidi Rule does not have to be applied to labels of the category LeftToRight.

functions.name: DirectionString
functions.desc: DirectionString reports the direction of the given label as defined by RFC 5893. The Bidi Rule does not have to be applied to labels of the category LeftToRight.

functions.name: Valid
functions.desc: Valid reports whether b conforms to the BiDi rule.

functions.name: ValidString
functions.desc: ValidString reports whether s conforms to the BiDi rule.

functions.name: Reset
functions.desc: Reset implements transform.Transformer.

functions.name: Span
functions.desc: Span returns the first n bytes of src that conform to the Bidi rule.

functions.name: Transform
functions.desc: Transform implements transform.Transformer. This Transformer has state and needs to be reset between uses.

functions.name: isRTL
functions.desc: A rule can only be violated for "Bidi Domain names", meaning if one of the following categories has been observed.

types.name: Transformer
types.desc: Transformer implements transform.Transform.

name: vendor/golang.org/x/text/transform
desc: Package transform provides reader and writer wrappers that transform the bytes passing through as well as various transformations. Example transformations provided by other packages include normalization and conversion between character sets.

functions.name: Append
functions.desc: Append appends the result of converting src[:n] using t to dst, where n <= len(src), If err == nil, n will be len(src). It calls Reset on t.

functions.name: Bytes
functions.desc: Bytes returns a new byte slice with the result of converting b[:n] using t, where n <= len(b). If err == nil, n will be len(b). It calls Reset on t.

functions.name: String
functions.desc: String returns a string with the result of converting s[:n] using t, where n <= len(s). If err == nil, n will be len(s). It calls Reset on t.

functions.name: grow
functions.desc: grow returns a new []byte that is longer than b, and copies the first n bytes of b to the start of the new slice.

functions.name: Reset
functions.desc: Reset implements the Reset method of the Transformer interface.

functions.name: Read
functions.desc: Read implements the io.Reader interface.

functions.name: Close
functions.desc: Close implements the io.Closer interface.

functions.name: Write
functions.desc: Write implements the io.Writer interface. If there are not enough bytes available to complete a Transform, the bytes will be buffered for the next write. Call Close to convert the remaining bytes.

functions.name: Reset
functions.desc: Reset resets the state of Chain. It calls Reset on all the Transformers.

functions.name: Transform
functions.desc: Transform applies the transformers of c in sequence.

functions.name: Transform
functions.desc: Transform implements the Transformer interface.

types.name: NopResetter
types.desc: NopResetter can be embedded by implementations of Transformer to add a nop Reset method.

types.name: Reader
types.desc: Reader wraps another io.Reader by transforming the bytes read.

types.name: SpanningTransformer
types.desc: SpanningTransformer extends the Transformer interface with a Span method that determines how much of the input already conforms to the Transformer.

types.name: Transformer
types.desc: Transformer transforms bytes.

types.name: Writer
types.desc: Writer wraps another io.Writer by transforming the bytes read. The user needs to call Close to flush unwritten bytes that may be buffered.

types.name: chain
types.desc: chain is a sequence of links. A chain with N Transformers has N+1 links and N+1 buffers. Of those N+1 buffers, the first and last are the src and dst buffers given to chain.Transform and the middle N-1 buffers are intermediate buffers owned by the chain. The i'th link transforms bytes from the i'th buffer chain.link[i].b at read offset chain.link[i].p to the i+1'th buffer chain.link[i+1].b at write offset chain.link[i+1].n, for i in [0, N).

name: vendor/golang.org/x/text/unicode/bidi
desc: Package bidi contains functionality for bidirectional text support.  See https://www.unicode.org/reports/tr9.  NOTE: UNDER CONSTRUCTION. This API may change in backwards incompatible ways and without notice.

functions.name: AppendReverse
functions.desc: AppendReverse reverses the order of characters of in, appends them to out, and returns the result. Modifiers will still follow the runes they modify. Brackets are replaced with their counterparts.

functions.name: ReverseString
functions.desc: ReverseString reverses the order of characters in s and returns a new string. Modifiers will still follow the runes they modify. Brackets are replaced with their counterparts.

functions.name: computeMultilineReordering
functions.desc: Return multiline reordering array for a given level array. Reordering does not occur across a line break.

functions.name: computeReordering
functions.desc: Return reordering array for a given level array. This reorders a single line. The reordering is a visual to logical map. For example, the leftmost char is string.charAt(order[0]). Rule L2.

functions.name: isRemovedByX9
functions.desc: isRemovedByX9 reports whether the type is one of the types removed in X9.

functions.name: isWhitespace
functions.desc: isWhitespace reports whether the type is considered a whitespace type for the line break rules.

functions.name: resolvePairedBrackets
functions.desc: resolvePairedBrackets runs the paired bracket part of the UBA algorithm.  For each rune, it takes the indexes into the original string, the class the bracket type (in pairTypes) and the bracket identifier (pairValues). It also takes the direction type for the start-of-sentence and the embedding level.  The identifiers for bracket types are the rune of the canonicalized opening bracket for brackets (open or close) or 0 for runes that are not brackets.

functions.name: in
functions.desc: in returns if x is equal to any of the values in set.

functions.name: Direction
functions.desc: Direction reports the directionality of the runs.  The direction may be LeftToRight, RightToLeft, Mixed, or Neutral.

functions.name: NumRuns
functions.desc: NumRuns returns the number of runs.

functions.name: Run
functions.desc: Run returns the ith run within the ordering.

functions.name: Direction
functions.desc: Direction returns the direction of the text of this paragraph.  The direction may be LeftToRight, RightToLeft, Mixed, or Neutral.

functions.name: IsLeftToRight
functions.desc: IsLeftToRight reports whether the principle direction of rendering for this paragraphs is left-to-right. If this returns false, the principle direction of rendering is right-to-left.

functions.name: Line
functions.desc: Line computes the visual ordering of runs for a single line starting and ending at the given positions in the original text.

functions.name: Order
functions.desc: Order computes the visual ordering of all the runs in a Paragraph.

functions.name: RunAt
functions.desc: RunAt reports the Run at the given position of the input text.  This method can be used for computing line breaks on paragraphs.

functions.name: SetBytes
functions.desc: SetBytes configures p for the given paragraph text. It replaces text previously set by SetBytes or SetString. If b contains a paragraph separator it will only process the first paragraph and report the number of bytes consumed from b including this separator. Error may be non-nil if options are given.

functions.name: SetString
functions.desc: SetString configures s for the given paragraph text. It replaces text previously set by SetBytes or SetString. If s contains a paragraph separator it will only process the first paragraph and report the number of bytes consumed from s including this separator. Error may be non-nil if options are given.

functions.name: prepareInput
functions.desc: Initialize the p.pairTypes, p.pairValues and p.types from the input previously set by p.SetBytes() or p.SetString(). Also limit the input up to (and including) a paragraph separator (bidi class B).  The function p.Order() needs these values to be set, so this preparation could be postponed. But since the SetBytes and SetStrings functions return the length of the input up to the paragraph separator, the whole input needs to be processed anyway and should not be done twice.  The function has the same return values as SetBytes() / SetString()

functions.name: Class
functions.desc: Class returns the Bidi class for p.

functions.name: IsBracket
functions.desc: IsBracket reports whether the rune is a bracket.

functions.name: IsOpeningBracket
functions.desc: IsOpeningBracket reports whether the rune is an opening bracket. IsBracket must return true.

functions.name: reverseBracket
functions.desc: TODO: find a better API and expose.

functions.name: Bytes
functions.desc: Bytes returns the text of the run in its original order.

functions.name: Direction
functions.desc: Direction reports the direction of the run.

functions.name: Pos
functions.desc: Pos returns the position of the Run within the text passed to SetBytes or SetString of the originating Paragraph value.

functions.name: String
functions.desc: String returns the text of the run in its original order.

functions.name: lookup
functions.desc: lookup returns the trie value for the first UTF-8 encoding in s and the width in bytes of this encoding. The size will be 0 if s does not hold enough bytes to complete the encoding. len(s) must be greater than 0.

functions.name: lookupString
functions.desc: lookupString returns the trie value for the first UTF-8 encoding in s and the width in bytes of this encoding. The size will be 0 if s does not hold enough bytes to complete the encoding. len(s) must be greater than 0.

functions.name: lookupStringUnsafe
functions.desc: lookupStringUnsafe returns the trie value for the first UTF-8 encoding in s. s must start with a full and valid UTF-8 encoded rune.

functions.name: lookupUnsafe
functions.desc: lookupUnsafe returns the trie value for the first UTF-8 encoding in s. s must start with a full and valid UTF-8 encoded rune.

functions.name: lookupValue
functions.desc: lookupValue determines the type of block n and looks up the value for b.

functions.name: assignBracketType
functions.desc: assignBracketType implements rule N0 for a single bracket pair.

functions.name: classBeforePair
functions.desc: classBeforePair determines which strong types are present before a Bracket Pair. Return R or L if strong type found, otherwise ON.

functions.name: classifyPairContent
functions.desc: classifyPairContent reports the strong types contained inside a Bracket Pair, assuming the given embedding direction.  It returns ON if no strong type is found. If a single strong type is found, it returns this type. Otherwise it returns the embedding direction.  TODO: use separate type for "strong" directionality.

functions.name: getStrongTypeN0
functions.desc: getStrongTypeN0 maps character's directional code to strong type as required by rule N0.  TODO: have separate type for "strong" directionality.

functions.name: locateBrackets
functions.desc: locateBrackets locates matching bracket pairs according to BD16.  This implementation uses a linked list instead of a stack, because, while elements are added at the front (like a push) they are not generally removed in atomic 'pop' operations, reducing the benefit of the stack archetype.

functions.name: matchOpener
functions.desc: matchOpener reports whether characters at given positions form a matching bracket pair.

functions.name: resolveBrackets
functions.desc: resolveBrackets implements rule N0 for a list of pairs.

functions.name: applyLevelsAndTypes
functions.desc: Applies the levels and types resolved in rules W1-I2 to the resultLevels array.

functions.name: assertOnly
functions.desc: Algorithm validation. Assert that all values in types are in the provided set.

functions.name: findRunLimit
functions.desc: Return the limit of the run consisting only of the types in validSet starting at index. This checks the value at index, and will return index if that value is not in validSet.

functions.name: resolveImplicitLevels
functions.desc: 7) resolving implicit embedding levels Rules I1, I2.

functions.name: resolveNeutralTypes
functions.desc: 6) resolving neutral types Rules N1-N2.

functions.name: resolveWeakTypes
functions.desc: Resolving weak types Rules W1-W7.  Note that some weak types (EN, AN) remain after this processing is complete.

functions.name: assignLevelsToCharactersRemovedByX9
functions.desc: Assign level information to characters removed by rule X9. This is for ease of relating the level information to the original input data. Note that the levels assigned to these codes are arbitrary, they're chosen so as to avoid breaking level runs.

functions.name: determineExplicitEmbeddingLevels
functions.desc: Determine explicit levels using rules X1 - X8

functions.name: determineIsolatingRunSequences
functions.desc: Definition BD13. Determine isolating run sequences.

functions.name: determineLevelRuns
functions.desc: determineLevelRuns returns an array of level runs. Each level run is described as an array of indexes into the input string.  Determines the level runs. Rule X9 will be applied in determining the runs, in the way that makes sure the characters that are supposed to be removed are not included in the runs.

functions.name: determineMatchingIsolates
functions.desc: determineMatchingIsolates determines the matching PDI for each isolate initiator and vice versa.  Definition BD9.  At the end of this function:    - The member variable matchingPDI is set to point to the index of the     matching PDI character for each isolate initiator character. If there is     no matching PDI, it is set to the length of the input text. For other     characters, it is set to -1.   - The member variable matchingIsolateInitiator is set to point to the     index of the matching isolate initiator character for each PDI character.     If there is no matching isolate initiator, or the character is not a PDI,     it is set to -1.

functions.name: determineParagraphEmbeddingLevel
functions.desc: determineParagraphEmbeddingLevel reports the resolved paragraph direction of the substring limited by the given range [start, end).  Determines the paragraph level based on rules P2, P3. This is also used in rule X5c to find if an FSI should resolve to LRI or RLI.

functions.name: getLevels
functions.desc: getLevels computes levels array breaking lines at offsets in linebreaks. Rule L1.  The linebreaks array must include at least one value. The values must be in strictly increasing order (no duplicates) between 1 and the length of the text, inclusive. The last value must be the length of the text.

functions.name: getReordering
functions.desc: getReordering returns the reordering of lines from a visual index to a logical index for line breaks at the given offsets.  Lines are concatenated from left to right. So for example, the fifth character from the left on the third line is  	getReordering(linebreaks)[linebreaks[1] + 4]  (linebreaks[1] is the position after the last character of the second line, which is also the index of the first character on the third line, and adding four gets the fifth character from the left).  The linebreaks array must include at least one value. The values must be in strictly increasing order (no duplicates) between 1 and the length of the text, inclusive. The last value must be the length of the text.

functions.name: isolatingRunSequence
functions.desc: Rule X10, second bullet: Determine the start-of-sequence (sos) and end-of-sequence (eos) types, either L or R, for each isolating run sequence.

functions.name: run
functions.desc: The algorithm. Does not include line-based processing (Rules L1, L2). These are applied later in the line-based phase of the algorithm.

types.name: Class
types.desc: Class is the Unicode BiDi class. Each rune has a single class.

types.name: Direction
types.desc: A Direction indicates the overall flow of text.

types.name: Option
types.desc: An Option is an option for Bidi processing.

types.name: Ordering
types.desc: An Ordering holds the computed visual order of runs of a Paragraph. Calling SetBytes or SetString on the originating Paragraph invalidates an Ordering. The methods of an Ordering should only be called by one goroutine at a time.

types.name: Paragraph
types.desc: A Paragraph holds a single Paragraph for Bidi processing.

types.name: Properties
types.desc: Properties provides access to BiDi properties of runes.

types.name: Run
types.desc: A Run is a continuous sequence of characters of a single direction.

types.name: bidiTrie
types.desc: bidiTrie. Total size: 15744 bytes (15.38 KiB). Checksum: b4c3b70954803b86.

types.name: bracketPair
types.desc: bracketPair holds a pair of index values for opening and closing bracket location of a bracket pair.

types.name: bracketPairs
types.desc: bracketPairs is a slice of bracketPairs with a sort.Interface implementation.

types.name: bracketType
types.desc: Bidi_Paired_Bracket_Type BD14. An opening paired bracket is a character whose Bidi_Paired_Bracket_Type property value is Open.  BD15. A closing paired bracket is a character whose Bidi_Paired_Bracket_Type property value is Close.

types.name: directionalStatusStack
types.desc: This stack will store the embedding levels and override and isolated statuses

types.name: level
types.desc: level is the embedding level of a character. Even embedding levels indicate left-to-right order and odd levels indicate right-to-left order. The special level of -1 is reserved for undefined order.

types.name: paragraph
types.desc: A paragraph contains the state of a paragraph.

name: vendor/golang.org/x/text/unicode/norm
desc: Package norm contains types and functions for normalizing Unicode strings.

functions.name: appendFlush
functions.desc: appendFlush appends the normalized segment to rb.out.

functions.name: combine
functions.desc: combine returns the combined rune or 0 if it doesn't exist.  The caller is responsible for calling recompMapOnce.Do(buildRecompMap) sometime before this is called.

functions.name: decomposeHangul
functions.desc: decomposeHangul writes the decomposed Hangul to buf and returns the number of bytes written.  len(buf) should be at least 9.

functions.name: decomposeSegment
functions.desc: decomposeSegment scans the first segment in src into rb. It inserts 0x034f (Grapheme Joiner) when it encounters a sequence of more than 30 non-starters and returns the number of bytes consumed from src or iShortDst or iShortSrc.

functions.name: decomposeToLastBoundary
functions.desc: decomposeToLastBoundary finds an open segment at the end of the buffer and scans it into rb. Returns the buffer minus the last segment.

functions.name: isJamoVT
functions.desc: Caller must ensure len(b) >= 2.

functions.name: nextComposed
functions.desc: nextComposed is the implementation of Next for forms NFC and NFKC.

functions.name: nextDecomposed
functions.desc: nextDecomposed is the implementation of Next for forms NFD and NFKD.

functions.name: nextMulti
functions.desc: nextMulti is used for iterating over multi-segment decompositions for decomposing normal forms.

functions.name: nextMultiNorm
functions.desc: nextMultiNorm is used for iterating over multi-segment decompositions for composing normal forms.

functions.name: patchTail
functions.desc: patchTail fixes a case where a rune may be incorrectly normalized if it is followed by illegal continuation bytes. It returns the patched buffer and whether the decomposition is still in progress.

functions.name: Append
functions.desc: Append returns f(append(out, b...)). The buffer out must be nil, empty, or equal to f(out).

functions.name: AppendString
functions.desc: AppendString returns f(append(out, []byte(s))). The buffer out must be nil, empty, or equal to f(out).

functions.name: Bytes
functions.desc: Bytes returns f(b). May return b if f(b) = b.

functions.name: FirstBoundary
functions.desc: FirstBoundary returns the position i of the first boundary in b or -1 if b contains no boundary.

functions.name: FirstBoundaryInString
functions.desc: FirstBoundaryInString returns the position i of the first boundary in s or -1 if s contains no boundary.

functions.name: IsNormal
functions.desc: IsNormal returns true if b == f(b).

functions.name: IsNormalString
functions.desc: IsNormalString returns true if s == f(s).

functions.name: LastBoundary
functions.desc: LastBoundary returns the position i of the last boundary in b or -1 if b contains no boundary.

functions.name: NextBoundary
functions.desc: NextBoundary reports the index of the boundary between the first and next segment in b or -1 if atEOF is false and there are not enough bytes to determine this boundary.

functions.name: NextBoundaryInString
functions.desc: NextBoundaryInString reports the index of the boundary between the first and next segment in b or -1 if atEOF is false and there are not enough bytes to determine this boundary.

functions.name: Properties
functions.desc: Properties returns properties for the first rune in s.

functions.name: PropertiesString
functions.desc: PropertiesString returns properties for the first rune in s.

functions.name: QuickSpan
functions.desc: QuickSpan returns a boundary n such that b[0:n] == f(b[0:n]). It is not guaranteed to return the largest such n.

functions.name: QuickSpanString
functions.desc: QuickSpanString returns a boundary n such that s[0:n] == f(s[0:n]). It is not guaranteed to return the largest such n.

functions.name: Reader
functions.desc: Reader returns a new reader that implements Read by reading data from r and returning f(data).

functions.name: Reset
functions.desc: Reset implements the Reset method of the transform.Transformer interface.

functions.name: Span
functions.desc: Span implements transform.SpanningTransformer. It returns a boundary n such that b[0:n] == f(b[0:n]). It is not guaranteed to return the largest such n.

functions.name: SpanString
functions.desc: SpanString returns a boundary n such that s[0:n] == f(s[0:n]). It is not guaranteed to return the largest such n.

functions.name: String
functions.desc: String returns f(s).

functions.name: Transform
functions.desc: Transform implements the Transform method of the transform.Transformer interface. It may need to write segments of up to MaxSegmentSize at once. Users should either catch ErrShortDst and allow dst to grow or have dst be at least of size MaxTransformChunkSize to be guaranteed of progress.

functions.name: Writer
functions.desc: Writer returns a new writer that implements Write(b) by writing f(b) to w. The returned writer may use an internal buffer to maintain state across Write calls. Calling its Close method writes any buffered data to w.

functions.name: transform
functions.desc: transform implements the transform.Transformer interface. It is only called when quickSpan does not pass for a given string.

functions.name: Done
functions.desc: Done returns true if there is no more input to process.

functions.name: Init
functions.desc: Init initializes i to iterate over src after normalizing it to Form f.

functions.name: InitString
functions.desc: InitString initializes i to iterate over src after normalizing it to Form f.

functions.name: Next
functions.desc: Next returns f(i.input[i.Pos():n]), where n is a boundary of i.input. For any input a and b for which f(a) == f(b), subsequent calls to Next will return the same segments. Modifying runes are grouped together with the preceding starter, if such a starter exists. Although not guaranteed, n will typically be the smallest possible n.

functions.name: Pos
functions.desc: Pos returns the byte position at which the next call to Next will commence processing.

functions.name: Seek
functions.desc: Seek sets the segment to be returned by the next call to Next to start at position p.  It is the responsibility of the caller to set p to the start of a segment.

functions.name: returnSlice
functions.desc: returnSlice returns a slice of the underlying input type as a byte slice. If the underlying is of type []byte, it will simply return a slice. If the underlying is of type string, it will copy the slice to the buffer and return that.

functions.name: BoundaryAfter
functions.desc: BoundaryAfter returns true if runes cannot combine with or otherwise interact with this or previous runes.

functions.name: BoundaryBefore
functions.desc: BoundaryBefore returns true if this rune starts a new segment and cannot combine with any rune on the left.

functions.name: CCC
functions.desc: CCC returns the canonical combining class of the underlying rune.

functions.name: Decomposition
functions.desc: Decomposition returns the decomposition for the underlying rune or nil if there is none.

functions.name: LeadCCC
functions.desc: LeadCCC returns the CCC of the first rune in the decomposition. If there is no decomposition, LeadCCC equals CCC.

functions.name: Size
functions.desc: Size returns the length of UTF-8 encoding of the rune.

functions.name: TrailCCC
functions.desc: TrailCCC returns the CCC of the last rune in the decomposition. If there is no decomposition, TrailCCC equals CCC.

functions.name: quickSpan
functions.desc: quickSpan returns a boundary n such that src[0:n] == f(src[0:n]) and whether any non-normalized parts were found. If atEOF is false, n will not point past the last segment if this segment might be become non-normalized by appending other runes.

functions.name: lookup
functions.desc: lookup returns the trie value for the first UTF-8 encoding in s and the width in bytes of this encoding. The size will be 0 if s does not hold enough bytes to complete the encoding. len(s) must be greater than 0.

functions.name: lookupString
functions.desc: lookupString returns the trie value for the first UTF-8 encoding in s and the width in bytes of this encoding. The size will be 0 if s does not hold enough bytes to complete the encoding. len(s) must be greater than 0.

functions.name: lookupStringUnsafe
functions.desc: lookupStringUnsafe returns the trie value for the first UTF-8 encoding in s. s must start with a full and valid UTF-8 encoded rune.

functions.name: lookupUnsafe
functions.desc: lookupUnsafe returns the trie value for the first UTF-8 encoding in s. s must start with a full and valid UTF-8 encoded rune.

functions.name: lookupValue
functions.desc: lookupValue determines the type of block n and looks up the value for b.

functions.name: lookup
functions.desc: lookup returns the trie value for the first UTF-8 encoding in s and the width in bytes of this encoding. The size will be 0 if s does not hold enough bytes to complete the encoding. len(s) must be greater than 0.

functions.name: lookupString
functions.desc: lookupString returns the trie value for the first UTF-8 encoding in s and the width in bytes of this encoding. The size will be 0 if s does not hold enough bytes to complete the encoding. len(s) must be greater than 0.

functions.name: lookupStringUnsafe
functions.desc: lookupStringUnsafe returns the trie value for the first UTF-8 encoding in s. s must start with a full and valid UTF-8 encoded rune.

functions.name: lookupUnsafe

functions.desc: lookupValue determines the type of block n and looks up the value for b.

functions.name: Read
functions.desc: Read implements the standard read interface.

functions.name: Close
functions.desc: Close forces data that remains in the buffer to be written.

functions.name: Write
functions.desc: Write implements the standard write interface.  If the last characters are not at a normalization boundary, the bytes will be buffered for the next write. The remaining bytes will be written on close.

functions.name: appendRune
functions.desc: appendRune inserts a rune at the end of the buffer. It is used for Hangul.

functions.name: assignRune
functions.desc: assignRune sets a rune at position pos. It is used for Hangul and recomposition.

functions.name: bytesAt
functions.desc: bytesAt returns the UTF-8 encoding of the rune at position n. It is used for Hangul and recomposition.

functions.name: combineHangul
functions.desc: combineHangul algorithmically combines Jamo character components into Hangul. See https://unicode.org/reports/tr15/#Hangul for details on combining Hangul.

functions.name: compose
functions.desc: compose recombines the runes in the buffer. It should only be used to recompose a single segment, as it will not handle alternations between Hangul and non-Hangul characters correctly.

functions.name: decomposeHangul
functions.desc: decomposeHangul algorithmically decomposes a Hangul rune into its Jamo components. See https://unicode.org/reports/tr15/#Hangul for details on decomposing Hangul.

functions.name: flush
functions.desc: flush appends the normalized segment to out and resets rb.

functions.name: flushCopy
functions.desc: flushCopy copies the normalized segment to buf and resets rb. It returns the number of bytes written to buf.

functions.name: insertCGJ
functions.desc: insertCGJ inserts a Combining Grapheme Joiner (0x034f) into rb.

functions.name: insertDecomposed
functions.desc: insertDecomposed inserts an entry in to the reorderBuffer for each rune in dcomp. dcomp must be a sequence of decomposed UTF-8-encoded runes. It flushes the buffer on each new segment start.

functions.name: insertFlush
functions.desc: insertFlush inserts the given rune in the buffer ordered by CCC. If a decomposition with multiple segments are encountered, they leading ones are flushed. It returns a non-zero error code if the rune was not inserted.

functions.name: insertOrdered
functions.desc: insertOrdered inserts a rune in the buffer, ordered by Canonical Combining Class. It returns false if the buffer is not large enough to hold the rune. It is used internally by insert and insertString only.

functions.name: insertSingle
functions.desc: insertSingle inserts an entry in the reorderBuffer for the rune at position i. info is the runeInfo for the rune at position i.

functions.name: insertUnsafe
functions.desc: insertUnsafe inserts the given rune in the buffer ordered by CCC. It is assumed there is sufficient space to hold the runes. It is the responsibility of the caller to ensure this. This can be done by checking the state returned by the streamSafe type.

functions.name: reset
functions.desc: reset discards all characters from the buffer.

functions.name: runeAt
functions.desc: runeAt returns the rune at position n. It is used for Hangul and recomposition.

functions.name: lookup
functions.desc: lookup determines the type of block n and looks up the value for b. For n < t.cutoff, the block is a simple lookup table. Otherwise, the block is a list of ranges with an accompanying value. Given a matching range r, the value for b is by r.value + (b - r.lo) * stride.

functions.name: backwards
functions.desc: backwards is used for checking for overflow and segment starts when traversing a string backwards. Users do not need to call first for the first rune. The state of the streamSafe retains the count of the non-starters loaded.

functions.name: first
functions.desc: first inserts the first rune of a segment. It is a faster version of next if it is known p represents the first rune in a segment.

functions.name: next
functions.desc: insert returns a ssState value to indicate whether a rune represented by p can be inserted.

types.name: Form
types.desc: A Form denotes a canonical representation of Unicode code points. The Unicode-defined normalization and equivalence forms are:  	NFC   Unicode Normalization Form C 	NFD   Unicode Normalization Form D 	NFKC  Unicode Normalization Form KC 	NFKD  Unicode Normalization Form KD  For a Form f, this documentation uses the notation f(x) to mean the bytes or string x converted to the given form. A position n in x is called a boundary if conversion to the form can proceed independently on both sides:  	f(x) == append(f(x[0:n]), f(x[n:])...)  References: https://unicode.org/reports/tr15/ and https://unicode.org/notes/tn5/.

types.name: Iter
types.desc: An Iter iterates over a string or byte slice, while normalizing it to a given Form.

types.name: Properties
types.desc: Properties provides access to normalization properties of a rune.

types.name: formInfo
types.desc: formInfo holds Form-specific functions and tables.

types.name: insertErr
types.desc: insertErr is an error code returned by insert. Using this type instead of error improves performance up to 20% for many of the benchmarks.

types.name: lookupFunc
types.desc: functions dispatchable per form

types.name: nfcTrie
types.desc: nfcTrie. Total size: 10332 bytes (10.09 KiB). Checksum: 51cc525b297fc970.

types.name: nfkcTrie
types.desc: nfkcTrie. Total size: 16994 bytes (16.60 KiB). Checksum: c3ed54ee046f3c46.

types.name: qcInfo
types.desc: We pack quick check data in 4 bits:  	5:    Combines forward  (0 == false, 1 == true) 	4..3: NFC_QC Yes(00), No (10), or Maybe (11) 	2:    NFD_QC Yes (0) or No (1). No also means there is a decomposition. 	1..0: Number of trailing non-starters.  When all 4 bits are zero, the character is inert, meaning it is never influenced by normalization.

types.name: reorderBuffer
types.desc: reorderBuffer is used to normalize a single segment.  Characters inserted with insert are decomposed and reordered based on CCC. The compose method can be used to recombine characters.  Note that the byte buffer does not hold the UTF-8 characters in order.  Only the rune array is maintained in sorted order. flush writes the resulting segment to a byte array.

types.name: ssState
types.desc: ssState is used for reporting the segment state after inserting a rune. It is returned by streamSafe.next.

types.name: streamSafe
types.desc: streamSafe implements the policy of when a CGJ should be inserted.

name: weak
desc: Package weak provides ways to safely reference memory weakly, that is, without preventing its reclamation.

functions.name: Value
functions.desc: Value returns the original pointer used to create the weak pointer. It returns nil if the value pointed to by the original pointer was reclaimed by the garbage collector. If a weak pointer points to an object with a finalizer, then Value will return nil as soon as the object's finalizer is queued for execution.

types.name: Pointer
types.desc: Pointer is a weak pointer to a value of type T.  Just like regular pointers, Pointer may reference any part of an object, such as a field of a struct or an element of an array. Objects that are only pointed to by weak pointers are not considered reachable, and once the object becomes unreachable, [Pointer.Value] may return nil.  The primary use-cases for weak pointers are for implementing caches, canonicalization maps (like the unique package), and for tying together the lifetimes of separate values (for example, through a map with weak keys).  Two Pointer values compare equal if and only if the pointers from which they were created compare equal. This property is maintained even after the object referenced by the pointer used to create a weak reference is reclaimed. If multiple weak pointers are made to different offsets within the same object (for example, pointers to different fields of the same struct), those pointers will not compare equal. In other words, weak pointers map to objects and offsets within those objects, not plain addresses. If a weak pointer is created from an object that becomes unreachable, but is then resurrected due to a finalizer, that weak pointer will not compare equal with weak pointers created after the resurrection.  Calling [Make] with a nil pointer returns a weak pointer whose [Pointer.Value] always returns nil. The zero value of a Pointer behaves as if it were created by passing nil to [Make] and compares equal with such pointers.  [Pointer.Value] is not guaranteed to eventually return nil. [Pointer.Value] may return nil as soon as the object becomes unreachable. Values stored in global variables, or that can be found by tracing pointers from a global variable, are reachable. A function argument or receiver may become unreachable at the last point where the function mentions it. To ensure [Pointer.Value] does not return nil, pass a pointer to the object to the [runtime.KeepAlive] function after the last point where the object must remain reachable.  Note that because [Pointer.Value] is not guaranteed to eventually return nil, even after an object is no longer referenced, the runtime is allowed to perform a space-saving optimization that batches objects together in a single allocation slot. The weak pointer for an unreferenced object in such an allocation may never become nil if it always exists in the same batch as a referenced object. Typically, this batching only happens for tiny (on the order of 16 bytes or less) and pointer-free objects.
